Original comment by: Carbon Monoxide
. Hi,
Could you try 'bp NtSetInformationThread' and stepping on this one: http://rghost.net/53342175
A friend of mine told me steam uses NtSetInformationThread as anti-debug trick to hide the thread from the debugger. This is a well-known anti-debug trick. You could try TitanHide to fix this anti-debug trick.
When I step over the SYSCALL, the debugger puts a breakpoint in the next instruction. After the SYSCALL, the debugger will no longer receive debug events from the thread, so there will be a crash (on the target, not on x64_dbg).
Please tell me if the crash is in x64_dbg or in the executable you're debugging.

Original comment by: alex_b3
. Yes to all, but especially xmm and ymm.  And here's my wish list for
display features for registers (I use FASM extensively, and need a better
debugger than WinDbg, which is barely adequate for 64-bit debugging):
- Have a "drill down" feature for the registers. For example, display the
  GP regs (rax, rbx, etc.; or eax, ebx, etc. for 32-bit code). But if I click
  on the + next to it, then also show eax, ax, ah and al, etc.
- For all displayed regs, show both signed and unsigned values (or make it
  simple to switch between them).
- Make it easy to switch between hex and decimal display.
- The flags should always be displayed
For xmm/ymm/zmm regs: xmm is a subset of ymm, ymm is a subset of zmm.  But,
we sometimes think of them as separate.  So:
- Show xmm, ymm, and zmm regs on separate lines with ability to drill down.
  - For example, in 64-bit code, when I click on ymm, show drop-down with
    all 32 regs.  Then let me see the data as bytes, words, dwords, etc., with
    option for signed/unsigned, hex/decimal, float/integers/byte display formats
- DO NOT close or modify the register display, let it remain as I set it;
  let me save the format so it is "remembered" each time.
- Bonus feature: allow me to change the display order. For example, I
  always need the flags, so I'll put that on top; but since I don't normally
  care about r12-r15, let me move those near the bottom.
Look at Microsoft WinDbg - has lots of format options for memory display
(this is good!), but lacks ability to change format of register display
(but it allows me to change the order of the registers).
Thanks,
ejamesr

Original comment by: David Reguera Garcia (Dreg)
. The FPU registers are not used by Windows in Win64 (I'm not sure about
MMX).  3dnow has been essentially dropped, no longer used.  But xmm (and
ymm and larger) regsiters are vital for Win64.  You can certainly show the
other regs; if Win64 doesn't use them, they won't get trashed during
context switches.

Original comment by: ejamesr
. Parsing 80-bit floats would just be the reverse operation of this function: https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/development/src/gui/Src/Utils/StringUtil.cpp#L38 (don't think anyone will need it though)
XMM/YMM/ZMM registers are not a single full-width variable. They're calculated as multiple 8/16/32/64 bit variables (floats or integers) depending on what instruction is used. The user would need to choose the display mode. (Assuming torusrxx is doing this)

Original comment by: alex_b3
. hey,
for you guys I will upload a release with all debug symbols needed for analysis, I had the issue a few times and it was hanging in TitanEngine in Global.Engine.Threading.cpp (the Mutex locks I failed to design). There were massive handle leaks (I forgot CloseHandle in the uninitializer of the class). According to Nukem x64_dbg still hang here, but I cannot reproduce it (not even with the exe alex_b3 uses). My testing environment was the 32-bit steam game Broforce, just run it in the debugger, play some and exit. The debugger would first hang (on GetContextThread), but later it didn't hang anymore.
In the past there were also issues with global variables being accessed from different threads (eg the SQLite database), these caused crashes, but they were fixed (I hope).
Greetings and thanks for investigating!

Original comment by: mrexodia
. ok, I checked it out again (this time not so tired as before) and I removed the locks on the TitanEngine context functions. When removing I noticed that I locked the "DBGContext" mutex before entering the function, so it looked like:
__declspec(dllexport) bool TITCALL SetContextDataEx(HANDLE hActiveThread, DWORD IndexOfRegister, ULONG_PTR NewRegisterValue)
{
    MutexLocker lock("DBGContext"); //the context is locked again here, this would cause the deadlock
    //do the actual setting of the context (irrelevant for this example)
}
__declspec(dllexport) bool TITCALL SetContextData(DWORD IndexOfRegister, ULONG_PTR NewRegisterValue)
{
    MutexLocker lock("DBGContext"); //the context is locked here
    SetContextDataEx(hThread, IndexOfRegister, NewRegisterValue);
}
I'm really sorry about this, I removed the global variable DBGContext (why was it even global in the first place?) and I also removed the locks (the functions used in this code are not marked as thread-unsafe). Hopefully it fixes the issue.
Download the latest dev version (+ debug symbols): https://mega.co.nz/#!L0wAnARK!QJmGQwWj_3hPAbqwWFOb99a1bUm3uFlt8c8lmZj23Dg

Original comment by: mrexodia
. This is already what happens right now. The reason the thing crashes is that I didn't clear the plugin list, which basically means it will try to call plugins that are unloaded using FreeLibrary.
There will not be any plugindestroy function. It is 100% useless, except for the fact that plugins can add a dialog to ask if users want to quit. If you want to do operations on target stop (like exit stack analysis or something), use the CB_DEBUG* functions. If you need to complete something, do it in the plugstop function. The debugger will wait for your stuff to be completed.
This was fixed in bf8c69b475b94417dfb2a86cd761c82a202bc2c6. Right now, when I leave the MultiASM window open and close the debugger it will simply close the MultiASM window and exit without crashes.

Original comment by: mrexodia
. > when I leave the MultiASM window open and close the debugger it will simply close the MultiASM window and exit without crashes.
I don't see how the commit you've linked fixes this issue. After all, the window procedure of multiasm is not called by x64_dbg, but by the system, so freeing the library right after calling plugstop still can cause a crash.
Also, I believe that introducing the plugindestroy callback function will lead to a cleaner, more correct API design. But in the end, it's your debugger and your choice. All I can say is that I'm reluctant to search for workarounds for crashes which are caused by this, while it works perfectly well with OllyDbg.

Original comment by: RaMMicHaeL
. The problem (which was an actual bug in x64_dbg) that was fixed by bf8c69b475b94417dfb2a86cd761c82a202bc2c6 had to do with when a global event message was sent to the event filter and then through CB_WINEVENTGLOBAL, the plugin callback processor would attempt to call the registered callback, even after plugstop was called, because the plugin list was not cleared. The commit ensured that the plugin list is cleared after plugstop, which means the CB_WINEVENTGLOBAL message would not be sent to freed plugins.
In your plugin you call PostMessage(WM_CLOSE);, which will not wait until the message was successfully processed. This means its a pure guess game if your window is closed before you return from plugstop. When the WM_CLOSE message is still being processed and at that moment the DLL is freed, it will generally crash. However, when you call SendMesssage(WM_CLOSE); instead, it will only return after you cleaned up your window, meaning you don't have to worry about random crashes.
Probably the only reason it works correctly in OllyDbg is that there is some delay between ODBG_Pluginclose and ODBG_Plugindestroy.
The answer to this question is interesting regarding this matter:

PostMessage (in "pure windows programming", aka win32 API) is asynchronous, i.e., to quote the docs:

Places (posts) a message in the message queue associated with the thread that created the specified window and returns without waiting for the thread to process the message.
To post a message in the message queue associated with a thread, use the PostThreadMessage function.```

SendMessage is synchronous, that is, again quoting:

Sends the specified message to a window or windows. The SendMessage function calls the window procedure for the specified window and does not return until the window procedure has processed the message.`
To send a message and return immediately, use the SendMessageCallback or SendNotifyMessage function. To post a message to a thread's message queue and return immediately, use the PostMessage or PostThreadMessage function.


Like I said before, adding a plugdestroy message would just be:
bool _dbg_exitsignal()
{
    if(!plugstop())
        return false; //do not exit
    //some other cleanup code
    plugdestroy();
    return true; //exit
}

No, there's no delay and no luck involved. I've tried to explain many times how OllyDbg manages this, but you don't seem to understand.
ODBG_Pluginclose is called early, right after you click on close. OllyDbg's main window still exists and shown, nothing was cleaned up, etc.
ODBG_Plugindestroy is called lately, after all GUI is finalized! The message loop is finalized as well, ALL the windows of the process are gone, so multiasm's windows procedure just CANNOT be called anymore. All is left for the process is to exit. You might want to look again at the five stages I written in the original bug report above.

The answer to this question is interesting regarding this matter:

Yes, but WM_CLOSE doesn't destroy the window right away. It just schedules a closing event.

Like I said before, adding a plugdestroy message would just be:

It shouldn't be like that! That obviously won't help!
It should be more like this:
```
void main()
{
    // ...
run_GUI(); // <-- on_exit_button_click() gets called here

// ...

before_termination();
exit_process();

}
bool on_exit_button_click()
{
    for(i=0; i<plugin_count; i++)
        if(!plugstop(i))
            return false; //do not exit
    return true; //exit
}
void before_termination()
{
    for(i=0; i<plugin_count; i++)
        plugdestroy(i);
}
```

Original comment by: RaMMicHaeL
. ok, here is a small overview of what happens when I click the close button on the x64dbg window: 
```
!c++
void MainWindow::closeEvent(QCloseEvent* event)
{
    hide(); //hide main window from sight (not the same as deleting)
    mCloseDialog->show(); //display 'Closing debugger...' dialog
    mCloseDialog->setFocus(); //set focus to this dialog
    CloseHandle(CreateThread(0, 0, closeThread, this, 0, 0)); //create closeThread
    if(bClose) //bClose = false on dialog init
        event->accept(); //accept event (close/destroy the main window)
    else
        event->ignore(); //ignore event (eg actually close the dialog) when bClose = false
}
```
After the closeEvent, x64_dbg will spawn a thread that does the following:
```
!c++
DWORD WINAPI MainWindow::closeThread(void ptr)
{
    static bool closing = false;
    if(closing) 
        return 0;
    closing = true; //ensure the thread doesn't run twice
    DbgExit(); //call exit of the Dbg
    MainWindow mainWindow = (MainWindow*)ptr; //get pointer to MainWindow class
    mainWindow->bClose = true; //allow the function above this to actually close the dialog
    mainWindow->close(); //call the closeEvent
    return 0;
}
```
the DbgExit function looks (globally) like this:
```
!c++
extern "C" DLL_EXPORT void _dbg_dbgexitsignal()
{
    cbStopDebug(0, 0); //stop debugging
    scriptabort(); //abort running scripts
    wait(WAITID_STOP); //after this, debugging stopped (wait for debugger to report it stopped)
    pluginunload(); //unload plugins
    TerminateThread(hCommandLoopThread, 0);
    CloseHandle(hCommandLoopThread);
    cmdfree(command_list);
    varfree();
    msgfreestack(gMsgStack);
    if(memleaks())
    {
        char msg[256] = "";
        sprintf(msg, "%d memory leak(s) found!\n\nPlease send 'alloctrace.txt' to the authors of x64_dbg.", memleaks());
        MessageBoxA(0, msg, "error", MB_ICONERROR | MB_SYSTEMMODAL);
    }
    else
        DeleteFileA(alloctrace);
    CriticalSectionDeleteLocks();
}
```
pluginunload looks like so:
```
!c++
void pluginunload()
{
    int pluginCount = (int)pluginList.size();
    for(int i = pluginCount - 1; i > -1; i--)
    {
        PLUGSTOP stop = pluginList.at(i).plugstop;
        if(stop)
            stop(); //call plugstop
        plugincmdunregisterall(pluginList.at(i).initStruct.pluginHandle); //unregister callbacks
        FreeLibrary(pluginList.at(i).hPlugin); //actually unload the library
        pluginList.erase(pluginList.begin() + i); //erase plugin from list to prevent calling callbacks in functions that do not exist
    }
    pluginCallbackList.clear(); //remove all callbacks
    pluginMenuList.clear(); //clear menu list
    GuiMenuClear(GUI_PLUGIN_MENU); //clear the plugin menu
}
```

Original comment by: mrexodia
. You are right about that it "feels awkward", but in my opinion x64_dbg is one of the few debuggers handling this thing correctly. Various debuggers handle INT3 commands as if they are breakpoints, meaning they swallow the exception, leaving the debugger open for detection mechanisms like:
```
!c++
BOOL TestDebuggerSwallowsException()
{
    __try
    {
        RaiseException(STATUS_BREAKPOINT, 0, 0, 0);
    }
    __except(1)
    {
        return FALSE; //all good, debugger did not swallow the exception
    }
    return TRUE; //debugger detected
}
```
Above code inspired from: http://www.autosectools.com/anti-debugging-with-exceptions.pdf
Simply ignoring exceptions is not supposed to happen, but to fix the awkwardness I added a command skip that simply sets the IP one instruction forward (in addition to swallowing the exception, so be careful using this).
The reason you had to repeat the process is first and second chance exceptions. First chance is before the exception is thrown at the debuggee. Second chance is after all possible handlers are called (could be none) and the application would normally crash. The skip command takes care of this for you.

Original comment by: mrexodia
. Thank you, having the 'skip' command is certainly an improvement.
I insert 'int3' commands at the points where I want my assembly-language
code to stop (this is in addition to any breakpoints I might set once the
debugger runs; in fact, this is the best way to set breakpoints at
strategic points in the code I'm debugging).  So, I prefer this be handled
exactly as a breakpoint, because each int3 I insert actually is a
breakpoint.  It is not an error (as is almost every exception), it is by
design.  I just want the program to stop at that point so I can inspect
memory, CPU flags, variables, etc.  Olydbg and Windbg handle this in the
way that makes debugging flow smoothly, exactly as a manually-place
breakpoint would do.
I have no experience with the detection methods you write about, so I can't
speak to that.  In any case, I look forward to testing the new version, thx!

Original comment by: mrexodia
. edit: you beat me anyway
Found out why: http://maximumcrack.wordpress.com/2009/06/22/outputdebugstring-awesomeness/
```
OUTPUT_DEBUG_STRING_EVENT behaves just like an exception event, so that if you continue with DBG_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED, it sends the event a second time, just like a second chance exception.
Recently I’ve been wondering why I got 2 debug string events for each call to OutputDebugString from the debuggee. I was looking for all sorts of weird solutions until I found out that returning DBG_CONTINUE did the trick.
```
https://bitbucket.org/mrexodia/titanengine-update/src/29f8973700c61a53f36f8f8247ea3ae3f909202a/TitanEngine/TitanEngine.Debugger.DebugLoop.cpp?at=master#cl-466

Original comment by: Matteo Favaro
. I can confirm and I think I can reproduce it.  
Place an hwbp somewhere, then:
Test 1:
run, you break on it for the first time: in the list you can see your HWBP
F7/sti/Step Into, you break on it for the second time (you didn't move): in the list your HWBP has disappeared
F7/sti/Step Into, you are on the subsequent instruction, just how it should be: your HWBP is there again!!!
Now you can issue a bphwc and set a new HWBP: the same slot will be used -> it has been effectively freed.
Test 2:
run, you break on it for the first time: in the list you can see your HWBP
now issue a bphwc, or just right click->Remove Hardware, the important thing is that you ask x64dbg to clear the HWBP: the slot is now empty as expected
F7/sti/Step Into, you break on it for the second time (you didn't move): in the list the slot is still empty -> good
F7/sti/Step Into, you are on the subsequent instruction: slot still empty
Now set a new hwbp: BOOM!!! The NEXT slot is used!!!  
The only loaded plugins when this has been tested were the default Scylla and MultiASM, no ScyllaHide in the way.
(BTW by slot I mean the DRx register in the registers pane)
(I'm sorry for the number of edits, gotta get used to MD's rules about linebreaks)

Original comment by: mrexodia
. Maybe I'm overreacting when talking about vs2010 but at time it was released it was not usable due to constant crashes, compatibility issues with SDKs and other things. Basically nobody used it in serious projects and simply skipped that version, but I suppose quite serious number of these could be already fixed and it is quite fine to use. If it is, then good for you.
Main points:
You can develop it on newest windows, but if you use old SDK it doesn't really matter. Even if you use the latest SDK, vs2010 can (and unfortunately - often do) quietly use headers installed with it (the old ones) over these in SDK.
I didn't experience any crashess too, I said only about compilation being based on old header files. Aand to answer the question, _FLOATING_SAVE_AREA structure no longer have Cr0NpxState member used in TitanEngine. If it compiles fine for you, then you are using old windows headers (aforementioned well-known issue with vs2010). 
Everything compiles fine on vs2013 with correct SDK headers (after little fixes on issues like this) so no need to waste your time if you don't plan to officially support it in near future. Just fix your headers :P

Original comment by: RaMMicHaeL
. I could reproduce it again, and it seems like the debugger hangs in a call to SymFromAddr, which uses a critical section internally.
The MSDN documentation says the following:

All DbgHelp functions, such as this one, are single threaded. Therefore, calls from more than one thread to this function will likely result in unexpected behavior or memory corruption. To avoid this, you must synchronize all concurrent calls from more than one thread to this function.

x64_dbg probably calls the DbgHelp functions from secondary threads too, which causes this behavior.
In general, while taking a brief look at the code of x64_dbg, I got the impression that it's not very thread-safe. Multithreading is very tricky in C++, every access to a global variable has to be synchronized, as well as every call to a third party (e.g. WinAPI) function which isn't designed to be thread safe.

Original comment by: RaMMicHaeL
. hm, i tried to be quite thread safe in general (mainly in stuff like module/label/breakpoint/whatever lists), but you're right. i never checked thread-safely for dbghelp functions. will add an issue for it.

Original comment by: mrexodia
. OpenFileMappingW fails with error 2, file not found.
Now, while debugging x64_dbg, I see that a call to CreateFileMappingW (called from titanengine) fails with error 5, access denied. If I run x64_dbg with admin rights, it indeed seems to work.
A couple of notes:
- I believe that it can be fixed by changing L"Global\\szLibraryName%X" to L"Local\\szLibraryName%X", unless x64_dbg is expected to be able to debug libraries which are loaded in a different session. I don't think x64_dbg is designed for these kinds of stuff, and if it is, it should probably be optional, as the use case is much less common.
- It would be much easier to spot the error if it would be written to the log.
- It would be great if x64_dbg would show the GetLastError value somewhere near the registers, like OllyDbg does.

. Okay, currently undocumented but it's implemented.


Executing: x96dbg.exe c:\test32.exe arg1 arg2 arg3
Runs x32dbg.exe "c:\test32.exe" ""arg1" "arg2" "arg3""
Which runs x32dbg.exe and executes the command init "c:\test32.exe", "arg1 arg2 arg3" effectively forwarding your command line arguments.

. I don't quite get the fuzz over this.. If you dislike the behaviour of the
step function, remove the hotkey, write a plugin command that has your
desired behavior and bind it to a hotkey.

The reason (even though I'm repeating myself) is for exception handling. If
you are holding f7 and this behavior were default it would swallow the
exception exposing the debugger for detection.
Also I'm not against people sending a pull request that doesn't change the
default behavior but adds an option to enable your desired behavior, I just
don't want to change the current behavior.

. Take a look at http://help.x64dbg.com/en/latest/introduction/index.html and make sure you understand how commands and expressions work. This section also contains information on exactly how conditional breakpoints are handled.

I think for your case the commands you're looking for would be:
bp 0x401000
SetBreakpointCondition 0x401000, "eax == 1". The prerequisite for any breakpoint is that you know where you want to break. If your question is: "Where is EAX equal to 5?" You can try conditional tracing, but this is very slow.
Ignore the bplist command. The breakpoint tab is all you need.. TraceIntoConditional "eax == 1". Ah nice, totally missed that one!

On Fri, 14 Aug 2015 04:46 wk notifications@github.com wrote:

... continued from above
Now to the new bug:
1- Again start debugging the exe file and reach the first line of the
"main()" function,
that should be @RVA https://github.com/RVA: 23E0
If that doesn't help, here are the opcodes of the "main()" if you want to
search for it as a pattern:
{ 40 57 48 83 EC 20 48 8B FC B9 08 00 00 00 B8 CC CC CC CC F3 AB 48 8D 15
64 A6 00 00 48 8B 0D 1D FD 00 00 E8 06 ED FF FF 33 C0 48 83 C4 20 5F C3 }
2- Now the 7th line/instruction (@VA https://github.com/VA:
7FF699A723F5 or @RVA https://github.com/RVA: 23F5) should be:
lea rdx, qword ptr ds:[7FF699A7CA60] // mov the address of "Hello World
\n" to RDX
assemble the following on that line:
mov qword ptr ds:[7FF7F672CA60], 0
unfortunately what gets assembled is:
mov qword ptr ds:[7FF7F672CA64], 0 // notice the increased 4 bytes
3- So now we know that with the instruction 'mov qword ptr [address]' the
address gets
increased by 4, let's assemble again but this time we'll remove 4 from the
address:
mov qword ptr ds:[7FF7F672CA5C], 0
what gets assembled is:
mov qword ptr ds:[7FF7F672CA60], 0
- This also applies to other forms of 'mov xxx ptr [address]', for
  example: 'mov byte ptr [address]' increases the address by 1
- This does not apply to the 32-bit version of the debugger, it's
  perfectly fine at this point.

On Sun, 8 Nov 2015 at 18:04, MeepDarknessMeep notifications@github.com
wrote:
plugincbcall(CB_BREAKPOINT, &bpInfo);
This line will break in some uncommon antidebugger tricks. There is an
undocumented function I have came across that will break under this line of
code running for every "int3" instruction.
RtlAddVectoredExceptionHandler from ntdll will set an exception handler,
and when int3 is ran, it will call the second argument to the function.
However, when you use x64dbg, it will go over the int3 and continue to the
opcode in front of it.
Solution
Only call plugincbcall(CB_BREAKPOINT, &bpInfo); when we have set the
breakpoint.

. I did some tests. VEH is working correctly:

```
include 
include 
LONG WINAPI VectoredHandler1(PEXCEPTION_POINTERS ExceptionInfo)
{
    puts("VectoredHandler1");
    return EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_SEARCH;
}
LONG WINAPI VectoredHandler2(PEXCEPTION_POINTERS ExceptionInfo)
{
    puts("VectoredHandler2");
    if (ExceptionInfo->ExceptionRecord->ExceptionCode == EXCEPTION_BREAKPOINT)
    {
ifdef _WIN64
    ExceptionInfo->ContextRecord->Rip++;

else
    ExceptionInfo->ContextRecord->Eip++;

endif
    return EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_EXECUTION;
}
return EXCEPTION_CONTINUE_SEARCH;

}
int main()
{
    puts("Start main()");
    AddVectoredExceptionHandler(1, VectoredHandler1);
    AddVectoredExceptionHandler(0, VectoredHandler2);
    __debugbreak();
    puts("End main()");
}
```
Output without debugger:
Start main()
VectoredHandler1
VectoredHandler2
End main()
Output with debugger:
Start main()
VectoredHandler1
VectoredHandler2
End main()
However when you add the line system("pause"); at the end of main, the output in the debugger will be:
Start main()
VectoredHandler1
VectoredHandler2
End main()
VectoredHandler1
VectoredHandler2
The log shows:
DebugString: "Application \"\\??\\C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe\" found in cache\n"
So this appears to be related to https://repo.palkeo.com/repositories/mirror7.meh.or.id/Todo/NtSetDebugFilterState.pdf (it does something with query filter state somewhere). It will be resolved by hiding the debugger in the PEB (use the dbh command).
The magic happens somewhere in ntdll.vDbgPrintExWithPrefixInternal in case somebody wants to research this. Did more checking, this function emits a DBG_PRINTEXCEPTION_C if PEB.BeingDebugged is true.

On Thu, 10 Dec 2015 at 18:39, Herz3h notifications@github.com wrote:
Found the fix, internally the breakpoint is reset everytime it's hit, and
in the reset if, it does this :
if(ResetBPX == true)
else if(ResetHwBPX == true)
else if(ResetMemBPX == true)
when it should be 3 If, so it sets back all breakpoints

On Sat, 19 Dec 2015 at 23:15, wk notifications@github.com wrote:
There is another problem here related to patched programs:
- Case 1:
- Debug any program, then place a SW BP anywhere.
- Change the instruction on which the BP is placed (so that the
  original bytes get changed).
- ## Restart the application
## The BP stays as it is (correct)
Case 2 (placing a BP after patching):
- Debug any program.
- Change any instruction then place a SW BP on it.
- Restart the application
- The BP gets disabled (wrong). This happens since of course the bytes
  after patching are the ones that get recorded, so on the next restart (when
  all the patches are lost) the original bytes are read and compared against
  the patch bytes ---> which will always be a mismatch.
Here's when it gets really annoying, assume you have the application
XXX.exe,
you've placed some SW BPs on that application, then after that you made
some patches,
and eventually saved it back to the file.
If you debugged the patched file, all your SW BPs will be disabled (case
2),
I know you did this to eliminate errors, for example in case the
application structure changed
(because of a new version maybe) and the BPs become misplaced which will
of course
cause exceptions, but what about this situation ?
Even if you recorded the original bytes before patching, the
above-mentioned scenario
of debugging the patched file will also fail
—

https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/issues/463#issuecomment-166030494.
. The reason this check was added is because someone reported an issue with
breakpoints set after unpacking and then causing weird decryption errors
during unpacking because the 0xCC bytes were placed in the region that is
zero on start.

An option with this extra behavior of not recording patch bytes sounds like
a good idea. I will check it.

On Mon, 7 Nov 2016 at 00:14, Matthijs Lavrijsen notifications@github.com
wrote:
Where are you people getting these magical NtQueryInformationProcess's
that return a cookie for any HANDLE other than NtCurrentProcess? I have
Windows 7 and even with debug privileges and a PROCESS_ALL_ACCESS handle I
can't query the cookie of another process.
I checked in IDA to be sure, and not only does the handle need to be to
the current process, it literally has to be (HANDLE)0xFFFFFFFF. Any other
value gives STATUS_INVALID_PARAMETER (0xC000000D), even if it is a valid
(non-pseudo) handle to your own process. I checked ReactOS since the
comment in MemDecodePointer references it, and they have the same
implementation:
if (((ProcessInformationClass == ProcessCookie) ||
    (ProcessInformationClass == ProcessImageInformation)) &&
    (ProcessHandle != NtCurrentProcess()))
{
    /*     * Retrieving the process cookie is only allowed for the calling process     * itself! XP only allows NtCurrentProcess() as process handles even if     * a real handle actually represents the current process.     */
    return STATUS_INVALID_PARAMETER;
}
Then I tried it on Windows 10 in a VM and there it works perfectly fine.
Disassembly of ntoskrnl.exe shows that you can now do it if you have 0x20 =
PROCESS_VM_WRITE access. I don't have Windows 8 to try so I can't say what
happens there, but it definitely doesn't work for me on 7.

. Unlike OllyDbg, x64dbg is fully portable (all paths are relative to the
x64dbg executables and in Olly you have absolute plugin and UDD paths).
This means you can copy you x64dbg.ini anywhere without having to change
anything.

Per default x64dbg will not create any registry entries. However if you use
it as a JIT debugger it will change that key. Same (as you mentioned) for
x96dbg.

. Great work!

I just checked, the call to ExHandlerGetSEH in stackcommentget is too much overhead (especially when there is more than 1 SEH entry). The main reason being that it is called ~20 times on each repaint. A possible solution is an unordered_map that gets populated in the updateSEHChainThread (making performance not matter) and then do lookups in this map in the stackcommentget function.
This requires a new SRW lock (threading.h). If you remove the part in stackcommentget I will accept the pull so people can have a dedicated SEH view to start with. Then the performance critical part can be updated later.
. You will always need locks because the map can be accessed from multiple
threads. Anyway stackcommentget is called on every redraw (which happens a
lot). See my previous comment for the location that is called when the
stack is modified (in the thread you create). I will try to make a code
example later this evening.

. Thanks a lot for your work, but this pull request will not be accepted as is. There are definitely changes I like a lot in this however. Please keep it open until I manually merged those in.

The rest looks great and I will make an effort to get them merged in as soon as possible!
. Just a quick comment. I didn't forget about this pull request but since I disagree with certain changes I have to manually merge the changes I want for which I don't have much time at the moment.
. I added the unicode support for symbol loading, the other parts still have to be added manually.
. Are you unable to load them or are you referring to strings not being recognized and such?
I didn't add the changes related to code pages yet and I'm currently not working on it. I also have some concerns regarding performance of the getFontWidth function. These being called in richTextPainter will probably drastically decrease single step performance.
. Today I implemented code page views in the HexDump. @polelf if this feature is okay for you, could you re-fork the project so I can merge your pull requests again? The rest of your changed should also be implemented.
. The name UTF-16 is confusing and I will change it. The only reason it exists is to print extended ASCII XX 00 characters. If you want to print real UTF-16 you can use the Text/Hex -> Codepage... option and it will print the text per-row and properly.
See here:
//This might produce invalid characters in variables-width encodings. This is currently ignored.
curData.text = desc.textCodec->toUnicode(QByteArray((const char*)wData, wBufferByteCount));
curData.text.replace('\t', "\\t");
curData.text.replace('\f', "\\f");
curData.text.replace('\v', "\\v");
curData.text.replace('\n', "\\n");
curData.text.replace('\r', "\\r");
richText.push_back(curData);
The reason I don't want to change the ASCII/UTF-16 is that certain non-English characters have a variable width (or even different from the English characters), so it makes per-unit printing/selection a complete hell.
I forgot to add the UTF-8 conversion in the HexEdit dialog and I will also add your change with the process handles.

. Yes I know. I plan to implement more flexible memory breakpoints (and tracing) in GleeBug.

Memory breakpoints will never be faster though. To set a memory breakpoint you need VirtualProtect (which is really slow), then VirtualProtect again on hit of the breakpoint (restore original protection), then single step with the trap flag and finally restoring the memory breakpoint with VirtualProtect. If you are going to break on every instruction you have three VirtualProtect calls overhead over the single step you would have done anyway.
As for coverage, it can be useful as supplementary data, but one path through your program is not enough to cover all branch decisions so it cannot be immediately discarded from analysis. I think it would be very interesting to see how many times certain instructions are executed to identify code/memory hotspots.
One feature that could be implemented with what is available right now is history debugging. This is just for every DebugUpdateGui storing some context and then allowing to view these contexts in the disassembler.
. Yes I think he was referring to the new breakpoint features.

On Sat, 20 Aug 2016 at 13:50, Torusrxxx notifications@github.com wrote:

This could be useful when calculating something after patching some code.
Proposed implementation:
command: call mydll:myfunction, stdcall, 1, 2, 3
Store the previous registers context, put some guard zeros on the stack,
then put the arguments on the stack and registers, other registers are
zeroed. Then put current RIP on the stack and set a software breakpoint on
RIP and continue execution at called function. When the function returns it
will stop at the breakpoint, and the registers are restored to previous
context, RAX,RDX are stored in $result and $result2.
An alternative way is to use zero as the return address, and capture that
exception then restore the context.
calling conventions:
x86: stdcall, cdecl, fastcall, thiscall
amd64: stdcall

I can't see anything wrong with the TE code per se, but that's mostly
because it's doing so much unnecessary work that it's hard to make out what
is really going on. But it also doesn't help that the AVX/XSTATE API in
Windows is nearly nonexistent apart from a single 10 year old MSDN page.
It seems to me that for this specific case (setting a single value, or
even setting ymm0-ymm15 all at once) there should be no need to call both
GetThreadContext and SetThreadContext more than once each. I get that
SetContextDataEx is supposed to be a generic multipurpose function, but
this is still something that reeks strongly of doing it wrong to me. Not
that I have any better suggestions at the moment - I'll have to read up on
the XSTATE API (or lack thereof). And you'll be hearing from my lawyer
about that 6700K.

. I have full control over all the calls to SymGetLineFromAddrW64 so no hooks are needed. But this is indeed the idea.  I have started implementing fast alternatives in symcache.cpp but I'm still thinking of a good way to populate that cache without completely lagging x64dbg on module load.
The issue lies in:

All DbgHelp functions, such as this one, are single threaded. Therefore, calls from more than one thread to this function will likely result in unexpected behavior or memory corruption. To avoid this, you must synchronize all concurrent calls from more than one thread to this function.

My current idea is to have a dedicated thread for dbghelp calls. Then on module load it calls DbgHelpThreadLoadModule which will immediately return and then populate the symbols in the background, putting them all in the cache at once to avoid any performance problems. I'm still thinking of downsides, but the only one I currently see is the additional complexity of managing an extra thread.. Ah that's a good one! In that case it'll signal the dbghelp thread that a
symbol enumeration was requested and if those symbols are still in progress
it will refresh the symbol list as soon as it can. In practice this will be
just a minor timing issue since the user is unlikely to immediately click
the symbol tab just after the module is loaded.

On Sun, 19 Jun 2016 at 13:53, fearless notifications@github.com wrote:
Might be handy to also expose certain default paths for plugins (and/or
scripts) to use:
Could be default variables obtained via a function call or a structure
passed back or something like that?
x64dbg_ini - stores a path to x32dbg.ini/x64dbg.ini for example
m:\x64dbg\x32\x32dbg.ini
x64dbg_root_folder - stores path to root folder containing exe -
m:\x64dbg\x64\
x64dbg_plugins_folder - stores path to plugins folder:
m:\x64dbg\x32\plugins\
x64dbg_db_folder - stores path to db folder: m:\x64dbg\x64\db\
Maybe a _plugin_getpaths function that returns a structure with the path
information populated for some locations that might be required.

. Just a quick note: disable this per default since it's not needed in most cases.
. Just did some changes to the TraceRecord, but it is far more efficient to store it per memory page instead of per 0x1000. I wrote StringUtils::ToCompressedHex which never produces bigger data but greatly compresses repeated bytes.

For example the data type map for overwatch.exe with a few defined types is:
00{A3F3}01{5}00{3}01{6}000001{3D}00{434}01{7}000001{27}00{7D2}01{A}000001{4}00{1706F7A}
. Yes, I was referring to the current trace record feature.

full trace record.

On Sun, 14 Aug 2016 at 15:51, Torusrxxx notifications@github.com wrote:
Proposed data to be recorded by the trace:
- RIP or EIP
- Code Bytes(Optional; Can be enabled by the user to disambigulate
  code in self-modifying code)
- Memory Data(When the instruction references a memory location)
- Registers Data(Record once every N instructions)
- Branch Destination and Source(Optional; Can be inferred from RIP
  change)
- Thread Name(Optional; Tracing can be single-threaded)
Unlike trace record, these data will not be stored per-byte, but will
stored in another global storage. We can add some index in the trace record
to allow easy access to these data from disassembler.
It is the data compression algorithm that blocks the development. This
algorithm should recognize every code re-execute and store these data only
once, and pack the huge amount of data in the tightest possible and also
extendable format. We can also export these data uncompressed.

. Qt calculates the width of every character for drawing the character. I checked with a performance profiler and the performance is really bad. Obviously checking multiple times (which RichTextPainter does) is bad, but that was 'fixed' by the font width cache.

I will still accept the fixed width unicode fix for the codepage views in the dump though, since it is kind of ugly there at the moment.
. Yes, I looked into it, but it has certain issues (for example in the disasm its completely useless and only drains performance). There is also a comment in RichTextPainter about using QTextLayout instead of the current rich text implementation, however this will break token selection amongst other things.

On Wed, 13 Jul 2016 at 16:51, jdavidberger notifications@github.com wrote:

Sure, but at no point do you have an exact counter right now -- it is
clearing itself, and at some points is doing so within 50ms of the last
time it cleared based on what the internal timings of the message queue
was.
Here is what I see as the possible ways to go with this, let me know which
you want and I'll change it to match:
1. Modify getdbgevents to remove the clearing behavior, and let the UI
   display both 'total events' which is clearable by the user, and possibly
   events in hertz. This would have benefit of being able to remove the
   interlock on that variable; and would allow other UI elements to use
   dbggetdbgevents -- currently they can't because two clients calling
   dbggetdbgevents would clear the event counter and each would get roughly
   half the information.
2. Revert out all the dbgevent changes. I don't think this is the best
   approach long term, but I think there is other useful stuff in this PR and
   I don't want to hold it up for what boils down to a minor UI change.

. The program crashed. The first chance exception was correctly passed to the
program and no exception handler handled it which means you get a crash
(last chance exception).

If you want to swallow the exception (generally a bad idea) you can use the
'con' command on the last chance exception. Generally this will introduce
the first chance exception again because you are in a crash state.

On Mon, 1 Aug 2016 at 19:47, wk notifications@github.com wrote:
I guess variable names like aaa, bbb, ccc, ddd, eee, fff
are not accepted because it seems that the variable name is being resolved
into a hex number.
In other words, var $eee, 123 and var $fff, 123 are exactly similar to
something like this:
var $7ee, 123
var $7ff, 123
which of course are not valid variable names since they start with a
number, hence eee and fff are not valid variable names.
I don't think it's a weakness in the expression parser though, think of a
situation like this:
var $qqq
mov qqq, 123
that would work fine, but if variable names with hex numbers were accepted
then it would be confusing to the debugger:
var $fff
mov fff, 123
@mrexodia https://github.com/mrexodia i guess a solution to this would
be restricting the dollar sign $ before var names, that way instructions
like mov $fff, 123 would be accepted since the user has explicitly marked
the token fff as a var name.

On Sat, 30 Jul 2016 at 14:41, soyasoya5 notifications@github.com wrote:
If the JMP instruction moves out of sight from the disassembly, the JMP
destination will not show any lines from the line that jumps to it.
For example, when the JMP is selected, the lines to the destination is
shown. http://puu.sh/qjFVH/7f6f7af800.png
However, if you select the destination and scroll down, moving the JMP
instruction out of sight, the line disappears.
http://puu.sh/qjFXK/2b29435f74.png
To find the JMP instruction, you'd have to search for references, which
you are unlikely to do if you don't know if there is a jump to the address
you selected.
In ollydbg, the JMP line is shown regardless if the instruction is in
sight or not. It even tells you where the jump is.
http://puu.sh/qjGsJ/5dc620c92f.png
I'd personally like to see this feature implemented as it might come in
handy.

savedata
Save a memory region to disk.
arguments
arg1: The filename. If you use :memdump: as name it will save a file as "memdump_pid_addr_size.bin" in the x64dbg directory.
arg2: The address of the memory region.
arg3: The size of the memory region.
results
This command does not set any result variables.

As for exports, x64dbg does not parse them in any way, it relies on dbghelp for the names of exports. If exports have symbols it will use that name instead of the export name. You can still access the export by using "module:ExportName" as x64dbg will try GetProcAddress on that module.
I have noticed issues with undecorated symbols, but it appears that private symbols do not have the decorated form stored:

All symbols are presented in undecorated form.
This option has no effect on global or local symbols because they are stored undecorated. This option applies only to public symbols.

Symbols are indeed treated as labels (and should be), you can find the exact code here, maybe you can see an error with dbghelp somewhere, the documentation for that is very poor.
Now, there has been a change related to security with the symbol options. Per default, x64dbg does not allow dbghelp to read the debug information of the program, since the symbol path can go to a network share which dbghelp will happily attempt to load from without warning or option to disable. You can try calling SymSetOptions(SymGetOptions() & ~SYMOPT_IGNORE_CVREC) from a plugin to see if it makes any difference.
. The documentation of SYMOPT_UNDNAME can be seen as calling UnDecorateSymbolName on every symbol during the loading and serving those names to SymFromAddr and SymEnum you lose all information about decorated symbols which is generally not what you want and also why x64dbg doesn't use that option.

The 'decorated' symbol <lambda_47baab08f63abb0acad11aadbc274841>::operator() can be found plaintext in the PDB and is a private symbol (therefore there is no mangled name stored since external components don't have to see is and thus it doesn't need an external mangled name).
I do have quite a lot of cases that don't have an undecorated form, one example: ??_7?$TaskThread_@P6AXXZ$$$V@@6B@

So I tried to get a quick "hacky" workaround going like this:
In symbolinfo.cpp add the line
SymEnumExports(Base, EnumCallback, UserData);
to the end of the SymEnum function.
SymEnumExports looks like this (as I said, just a quick "hacky" version):
void SymEnumExports(duint Base, CBSYMBOLENUM EnumCallback, void* UserData)
{
SYMBOLINFO symbol;
memset(&symbol, 0, sizeof(SYMBOLINFO));
symbol.isImported = false;
apienumexports(Base, &
{
symbol.addr = addr;
symbol.decoratedSymbol = (char *)name;
symbol.undecoratedSymbol = (char *)name;
EnumCallback(&symbol, UserData);
});
}
It now shows exported functions in the Symbols window, but the CPU window
still doesn't recognize exports :(

. @0x900x90 implemented this:
``` c++
void CPUDisassembly::copySelectionToFileSlot()
{
    QString fileName = QFileDialog::getOpenFileName(this, tr("Open File"), "", tr("Text Files (*.txt)"));
if(fileName != "")
{
    QFile file(fileName);

    if(!file.open(QIODevice::WriteOnly | QIODevice::Text))
    {
        QMessageBox::critical(this, tr("Error"), tr("Could not open file"));
        return;
    }

            QTextStream stream(&file);
    QList<Instruction_t> instBuffer;
    prepareDataRange(getSelectionStart(), getSelectionEnd(), &instBuffer);
    QString clipboard = "";
    const int addressLen = getColumnWidth(0) / getCharWidth() - 1;
    const int bytesLen = getColumnWidth(1) / getCharWidth() - 1;
    const int disassemblyLen = getColumnWidth(2) / getCharWidth() - 1;

    for(int i = 0; i < instBuffer.size(); i++)
    {
      if(i)
        clipboard += "\r\n";
      dsint cur_addr = rvaToVa(instBuffer.at(i).rva);
      QString address = getAddrText(cur_addr, 0);
      QString bytes;
      for(int j = 0; j < instBuffer.at(i).dump.size(); j++)
      {
        if(j)
            bytes += " ";
        bytes += QString("%1").arg((unsigned char)(instBuffer.at(i).dump.at(j)), 2, 16, QChar('0')).toUpper();
      }
      QString disassembly;
      for(const auto & token : instBuffer.at(i).tokens.tokens)
        disassembly += token.text;
      QString fullComment;
      QString comment;
      if(GetCommentFormat(cur_addr, comment))
        fullComment = " " + comment;
      clipboard += address.leftJustified(addressLen, QChar(' '), true);
      if(copyBytes)
        clipboard += " | " + bytes.leftJustified(bytesLen, QChar(' '), true);
      clipboard += " | " + disassembly.leftJustified(disassemblyLen, QChar(' '), true) + " |" + fullComment;
      if(clipboard.size()>4194304)
      {
        stream << clipboard;
                    stream.flush();
                    clipboard = "";
      }
    }
    file.close();
}

}
```

On Wed, 21 Sep 2016 at 09:32, faltur notifications@github.com wrote:
A suggestion to make our lives easier.
When the user right-clicks a line on the disassembler window, the dbg
shows the context menu option "Create class/structure for", and he will be
able to select a register or a memory address.
Example:
00A9F11F push ebp
00A9F120 mov ebp,esp
00A9F122 push ecx
00A9F123 mov dword ptr ss:[ebp-4],ecx ; <<< the line selected by user
00A9F126 mov eax,dword ptr ss:[ebp-4]
00A9F129 xor ecx,ecx
00A9F12B cmp dword ptr ds:[eax+1C],0
00A9F12F sete cl
00A9F132 mov al,cl
00A9F134 leave
00A9F135 ret
When the user selects the line 00A9F123 and right clicks it, he will be
able to create a class/structure for ECX or EBP-4. A new dialog box is
shown.
The "Create class/struct" dialog box contains the following input fields:
- an edit box to enter a new label for the selected address, and
- a multi-lined edit box (plainText) for the class/structure itself.
  The user can type a complete class or structure inside this field in C++.
  The name of the class/struct will be obtained from their definition.
Example of input class:
class MyClass
{
public:
virtual void start();
virtual void stop();
virtual int getB();
virtual WORD getC();
private:
int m_B;
BYTE m_C;
BYTE m_D;
WORD m_E;
DWORD m_F;
char m_text[16];
}
In the dump window, the user will be able to view the selected address as
a class/structure by right-clicking it and choosing "Show as
class/strucure", as follows:
; ASCII view
0019AA00 44 33 22 11 BB BB BB BB 66 55 EE EE FF FF FF FF ................
0019AA10 31 32 33 34 35 36 37 38 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 12345678........
; Class/Structure view
Address | Type | Field | Value
0019AA00 | void* | vtable | 11223344
0019AA04 | int | m_B | BBBBBBBB
0019AA08 | BYTE | m_C | 66
0019AA09 | BYTE | m_D | 55
0019AA0A | WORD | m_E | EEEE
0019AA0C | DWORD | m_F | FFFFFFFF
0019AA10 | char[] | m_text | "12345678" (Ansi)
All the registered structures/classes recognized by the dbg will be

. You can change this behavior in the settings file.

c++
duint setting;
if(BridgeSettingGetUint("GUI", "NonprintReplaceCharacter", &setting))
    mNonprintReplace = QChar(uint(setting));
if(BridgeSettingGetUint("GUI", "NullReplaceCharacter", &setting))
    mNullReplace = QChar(uint(setting));
Change both to 2e to have dots back. Notice that dots are not the actual representation of the character, they are only shown in place of non-printable characters and these non-ascii characters are inserted so it is easier to see the difference between dots (round dot for null characters and square for other nonprintables).
Also I'm open to discussion about what is better behavior and if the majority of people thinks dots/spaces are better than non-ascii characters I'll make that the default and a setting for the behavior I think is better.

Consider the following example:
mov eax, dword ptr ds:[ecx]
Since the destination is eax, which is 32-bit register, and the

option in x64dbg.

particular case it is obviously redundant and makes the code too verbose,
not helping to read and understand it. I believe that is the reason why IDA

first post. For example, mov dword ptr ds[ecx], 5 size directive is
absolutely necessary because 5 could be anything from byte to dword.

For which the only interesting one is 005A3866

The reason for this is that x64dbg linearly disassembles the executable to find string references and this part of code is mixed with data which means that 005A3866 is not disassembled. As you can see, the actual reference to the string is correctly detected when viewing the code.
The other undetected strings are some kind of Delphi string format (size,data) that I don't plan to support.

. Sorry about that, the fixed I pushed was inadequate. It has now been updated and the stack position will be [rsp+20] when the disassembly is on the call instruction. You can use this in conjunction with the checkbox mode on 'Calls' to only update the arguments widgets when on calls.


. Unlocked means the widget updates when the disassembly updates (eg on stepping)
Locked means the widget will not update (contents will stay the same even if you step)
Calls means the widget will only update if the disassembly is on a call instruction.. Also it shows as valid information as it can. If not on a call it will take the return address in account for stack space, but registers are volatile so obviously it cannot keep those valid.. Use the symbol tab to view imports/exports for modules and you can use the find intermodular calls option to find called functions with a name.. Indeed you can use the search for intermodular calls for that as I
mentioned.

I just tested this, but the function for enumHeaps is very, very, very slow on x64 (it takes minutes) and there seems to be no way to refresh a single view manually.

I checked some more and it looks like the function that CreateToolhelp32Snapshot uses to take a snapshot of the heap uses some kind of RPC. This function is RtlQueryProcessDebugInformation it uses NtCreateThreadEx in the debuggee to call RtlpQueryProcessDebugInformationRemote so heap enumeration will never complete if the debuggee is paused.. I did some more testing and the official API appears to be completely broken. The Address field after enumeration is totally broken. that's the main problem...
On Mon, 13 Feb 2017 at 06:01, Matthijs Lavrijsen notifications@github.com
wrote:

That blog entry has the right idea; unfortunately he has some incomplete
type info which (for me at least) caused the heap enumeration to crash, and
since the code uses hardcoded pointer offsets instead of types, I don't
really feel like figuring out the cause.
The Process Hacker headers should help if you're interested in using the
method from the blog with proper type info:
RTL_HEAP_ENTRY
https://github.com/processhacker2/processhacker2/blob/b443aa77ffd5072689f31d1a9e9d1799f8aad523/phnt/include/ntrtl.h#L3224
RTL_HEAP_TAG
https://github.com/processhacker2/processhacker2/blob/b443aa77ffd5072689f31d1a9e9d1799f8aad523/phnt/include/ntrtl.h#L3254
RTL_HEAP_INFORMATION
https://github.com/processhacker2/processhacker2/blob/b443aa77ffd5072689f31d1a9e9d1799f8aad523/phnt/include/ntrtl.h#L3264
(DEBUG_HEAP_INFORMATION in the blog)
RTL_PROCESS_HEAPS
https://github.com/processhacker2/processhacker2/blob/b443aa77ffd5072689f31d1a9e9d1799f8aad523/phnt/include/ntrtl.h#L3281
(blog: HeapInfo)
RTL_DEBUG_INFORMATION
https://github.com/processhacker2/processhacker2/blob/b443aa77ffd5072689f31d1a9e9d1799f8aad523/phnt/include/ntrtl.h#L3905
(blog: DEBUG_BUFFER)
The following ntdll functions are needed:
NTSYSAPI
PRTL_DEBUG_INFORMATION
NTAPIRtlCreateQueryDebugBuffer(
  In_opt ULONG MaximumCommit,
  In BOOLEAN UseEventPair
);
NTSYSAPI
NTSTATUS
NTAPIRtlDestroyQueryDebugBuffer(
  In PRTL_DEBUG_INFORMATION Buffer
);
NTSYSAPI
NTSTATUS
NTAPIRtlQueryProcessDebugInformation(
  In HANDLE UniqueProcessId,
  In ULONG Flags,
  Inout PRTL_DEBUG_INFORMATION Buffer
);
I would say using ntdll functions for heap enumeration is preferable to
CreateToolhelp32Snapshot and co by far. They may be undocumented but at
least they work. (and are orders of magnitude faster.)
Re: RtlpQueryProcessDebugInformationRemote and pausing: I know ntdll
expressly creates this thread using NtCreateThreadEx with
THREAD_CREATE_FLAGS_HIDE_FROM_DEBUGGER set in order to prevent these
kinds of issues. Whether that is enough to prevent all problems I don't
know. I recall at least one instance when I found out a program was
deadlocked because of an RtlQueryProcessDebugInformation call that was
issued by another process.

On Mon, 13 Feb 2017 at 13:00, Matthijs Lavrijsen notifications@github.com
wrote:
Yes, that's what I thought as well. THREAD_CREATE_FLAGS_HIDE_FROM_DEBUGGER
is very powerful, to the point where a thread with the flag set may even be
ignored when a process suspend is issued (though don't quote me on this),
but it's not enough to start execution in a process that's already
suspended, which would be the case here. I know because I wrote an
implementation of NtCreateThreadEx for the XP kernel once, ironically
with the purpose of banning this flag altogether as a ScyllaHide-type hook,
and I ended up having to special-case the ntdll debug heap query thread to
essentially give it godmode powers to prevent issues with suspended
threads. (and processes, which from the kernel's POV are nothing more than
processes containing only suspended threads, though it may lie and say each
thread's individual suspend count is 0).
There's no reason why RtlpQueryProcessDebugInformationRemote couldn't be
implemented out-of-process using ReadProcessMemory however. You'd simply
have to calculate the offsets, basically like the guy in the blog already
did minus the crash, and then issue a ReadProcessMemory for each
individual node and block. It would be slower, but not by that much;
NtReadVirtualMemory is very fast (it doesn't really care if the virtual
address you're reading is in your own process or another one after it has
performed the access checks). This would allow doing the enumeration in the
debugger while the debuggee is suspended. It might be preferable to do it
this way regardless since it removes the dependency on the ntdll imports.
You'd still be reliant on the undocumented heap node structure layout, but
that struct hasn't been changed in a looong time. I'm not saying I have a
copy of the leaked NT4 source from 1995 because that would be illegal, but
if I did, I might find the exact same struct as the one linked above in
there.

On Mon, 20 Feb 2017 at 16:36, Matthijs Lavrijsen notifications@github.com
wrote:
I noticed threads were always being shown as being in the "executive" wait
state, which I found a bit silly because WrExecutive is normally reserved
for the kernel. Taking a look at the source I found ThreadGetWaitReason was
actually unimplemented :P So that would explain it.
This is an implementation that uses
NtQuerySystemInformation(SystemProcessInformation), the only possible way
to get the thread wait reason.
It is monstrously inefficient because it gets info on all running
processes AND all of their threads (even though we only need one piece of
info on one thread). It could be made more efficient by at least caching
the results for the whole process so that ThreadGetWaitReason would only
have to be called once per process instead of for every thread. But that
would require some restructuring of how the thread info is queried right
now. There's also no reason to loop over the threads of processes we
already know aren't the debuggee, but I found no easy way to get the PID
from the THREADALLINFO that ThreadGetList makes. There is
GetProcessIdOfThread, but it isn't available on XP. Anyway, even with all
this I tested the performance and it came in at under 1 ms per call, so
it's actually not too bad. Since the thread list only gets refreshed once
per second it should be acceptable.

On Tue, 21 Feb 2017 at 21:14, Matthijs Lavrijsen notifications@github.com
wrote:
I said under 1 ms, not 1 ms :)
I just profiled it with a high accuracy timer and it came in at 0.159 ms
per call (this is on a Core i7 6700K). I expected the constant memory
allocations to be a contributing factor, but 99.46% (!) of the time was
used by NtQuerySystemInformation itself. It's a really expensive syscall.
One thing that could be done is change the signature of
ThreadGetWaitReason to ThreadGetWaitReason(std::unordered_map&) and call it once in ThreadGetList with the thread list so
it could do all the thread ID comparisons in one go. If it could also have
the PID from somewhere that would be nice, but I wouldn't do an
NtQueryInformationThread for it if it can be helped. I wouldn't bet money
on another added syscall being faster than just doing a few hundred integer
comparisons.

. duplicate of #1448. I think it's definitely a nice change, however it breaks the style of every other symbolic name in x64dbg ntdll.NtQueryInformationProcess+4C for example. It also doesn't respect the symbol undecoration setting or the symbol filter. I would suggest changing the stackinfo.cpp:getSymAddrName function instead (with some of the code from _exports.cpp:getLabel to handle the setting and the filter). That way this is also supported in the normal stack...

EDIT: It appears to be already supported, but only for user-defined or analyzed functions. I will push support for symbol displacement (apparently forgot when implementing it originally). As for the call stack, dbghelp is making up a lot of garbage (both for the callstack and for the symbol displacement) but there isn't much to be done about that I guess.... The performance wouldn't change, because SymFromAddr is already called in getSymAddrName. As for the undecoration, perhaps it's a good idea to change the default?. Hm, so how would we go about parsing the names like windbg does? I definitely think the extended C++ definitions are too much. Perhaps https://bitbucket.org/Nukem9/demangle could help?. Hm those flags are rather interesting. It should reduce the footprint of demangled C++ functions in the disassembly/call stack. For the symbol enumeration we can still fully demangle them for completeness.
As for __imp, there is an option that filters out certain names: https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/development/src/dbg/_exports.cpp#L117
And do you know if the isx86module() function makes any sense to use in x64dbg? I don't quite get what that check is supposed to do.... Oh, my tests for that hacky C-style string manipulation function:
```c++
// Example program
include 
include 
include 
// https://github.com/llvm-mirror/llvm/blob/2ae7de27f7d9276e7bada445ea7576bbc4c83ae6/lib/DebugInfo/Symbolize/Symbolize.cpp#L427
// Undo these various manglings for Win32 extern "C" functions:
// cdecl       - _foo
// stdcall     - _foo@12
// fastcall    - @foo@12
// vectorcall  - foo@@12
// These are all different linkage names for 'foo'.
static char demanglePE32ExternCFunc(char SymbolName)
{
    // Only do this for Win32
ifdef _WIN64
return SymbolName;

endif //_WIN64
// Remove any '_' or '@' prefix.
char Front = SymbolName[0];
if(Front == '_' || Front == '@')
    SymbolName++;

// Remove any '@[0-9]+' suffix.
if(Front != '?')
{
    auto AtPos = strrchr(SymbolName, '@');
    if(AtPos)
    {
        auto p = AtPos + 1;
        while(*p && isdigit(*p))
            p++;

        // All characters after '@' were digits
        if(!*p)
            *AtPos = '\0';
    }
}

// Remove any ending '@' for vectorcall.
auto len = strlen(SymbolName);
if(len && SymbolName[len - 1] == '@')
    SymbolName[len - 1] = '\0';

return SymbolName;

}
void testUnmangle(const char* x)
{
    std::cout << "1: " << x << std::endl;
    char t[256] = "";
    strcpy_s(t, x);
    std::cout << "2: " << demanglePE32ExternCFunc(t) << std::endl;
}
int main()
{
    testUnmangle("_foo");
    testUnmangle("_foo@12");
    testUnmangle("@foo@12");
    testUnmangle("foo@@12");
    testUnmangle("_LdrpDoDebuggerBreak@0");
    getchar();
}

```c++
include 
include 
HANDLE hFile;
struct BufferedWriter
{
    explicit BufferedWriter(HANDLE hFile, size_t size = 65536)
        : hFile(hFile),
        mBuffer(new char[size]),
        mSize(size),
        mIndex(0)
    {
        memset(mBuffer, 0, size);
    }
bool Write(const void* buffer, size_t size)
{
    return Write((const char*)buffer, size);
}

bool Write(const char* buffer, size_t size)
{
    for(size_t i = 0; i < size; i++)
    {
        mBuffer[mIndex++] = buffer[i];
        if(mIndex == mSize)
        {
            if(!flush())
                return false;
            mIndex = 0;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

~BufferedWriter()
{
    flush();
    delete[] mBuffer;
    CloseHandle(hFile);
}

private:
    HANDLE hFile;
    char* mBuffer;
    size_t mSize;
    size_t mIndex;
bool flush()
{
    if(!mIndex)
        return true;
    DWORD written;
    auto result = WriteFile(hFile, mBuffer, DWORD(mIndex), &written, nullptr);
    mIndex = 0;
    return !!result;
}

};
extern "C" __declspec(dllexport) void peeker()
{
    int count = 0;
    {
        BufferedWriter bufWriter(hFile);
        MSG msg;
    while(PeekMessageW(&msg, 0, 0, 0, PM_REMOVE))
    {
        bufWriter.Write(&msg, sizeof(msg));
        count++;
    }
}
char fuck[128] = "";
sprintf_s(fuck, "%d messages fucked", count);
MessageBoxA(0, fuck, "fuck!", MB_SYSTEMMODAL);

}

The process definitely seems to be using some anti-debug protections: the
attach breakpoint gets overwritten to cause an AV, and there are various
pages containing syscall stubs that syscalls get routed through via
exception handlers (mfc120.dll involved? My bet is yes.) On an x86 OS it
will simply patch KiFastSystemCall
https://www.malwaretech.com/2014/06/usermode-system-call-hooking-betabo.html
to intercept all syscalls. This gave me a nice BSOD when the AFD device was
ZwClosed incorrectly. Perhaps they should stick to writing user mode code.
Anyway, anti-debug isn't new, the question is how are they managing to
deadlock debuggers this way? I gave it a quick look in a kernel debugger
but nothing stood out: there are no pending IRPs or ALPC messages, and the
ERESOURCE win32k is trying to get does eventually get acquired exclusively
without shared waiters.

{

. Yeah I saw the issue before. The reason this happens is that Run to user code will actually execute the command TraceIntoConditional !mod.party(cip). Since the wow64 code is not associated with a module it will kinda fail there. I guess there are two possible solutions:


Change the condition to explicitly mention the ljmp and ignore that
Change to TraceOverConditional
Add the wow64 pages as modules

Downsides:

Will work with standard code but would fail if the syscalls are hooked (ScyllaHide)
Won't work in certain cases (eg abnormal control flow in system structure)
Undocumented so might be annoying.. The reason was the WOW64 layer. If the instruction executed is ljmp 33,XXXXXXXX to switch to 64 bit the stepping will be messed up for some reason... I made the requirements for the workaround less strict and TraceIntoConditional now works fine (it will terminate after 50k steps on clicking OK). I switched to TraceOverConditional because it's better in pretty much every way.

wrote:
This PR makes x64dbg compile and run using Clang/C2 from VS2017. The main
goal of this is to add Clang's impressive diagnostics and warnings for
additional compile time error checking. (There are a lot of warnings
currently, but I've kept the changes to the minimum required to get the
project to compile.)
Some notes:

The launcher (x96dbg.exe) still requires MSVC to compile due to the
   ATL headers being... well, special. I haven't managed to get the project to
   compile without modifying the ATL headers, which is probably going a bit
   too far.
The GUI DLL also requires MSVC, but this is more due to Qt's build
   system's lack of support for Clang/C2. It could probably be made to work
   with enough violence (given that Qt does support Clang/LLVM on Windows),
   but I'm not really interested in this.
Clang/C2 from VS2015 doesn't work, due to some MS header
   deficiencies that seem to have been fixed in VS2017.
Clang with LLVM also works (as in: compiles). I tested this with the
   Clang 5.0 alpha from SVN. I haven't even tried running the result though as
   the MSVC and LLVM ABIs are binary incompatible. Getting this to run would
   require compiling all dependencies including Qt with Clang/LLVM.

Most of the changes are non-functional, such as added type casts and uses
of 'this' in virtual template methods. There are some exceptions though:

getLastExceptionInfo() now returns EXCEPTION_DEBUG_INFO by reference
   rather than by value. This is to get the following to work:

getLastExceptionInfo().ExceptionRecord.ExceptionCode = 0;
To be honest I'm not sure how this even compiles in MSVC. It's possible
that this only 'works' currently by modifying a local copy, i.e.
effectively a no-op.

for(auto & i = windowsList.cbegin(); i != windowsList.cend(); i++):
   I've changed this to simply auto (i.e. non-reference). I don't feel
   bad for this as casting an rvalue to a reference this way is a nonstandard
   MS construct.
The LOADEXPORT macro has been changed to print (in case of error)
   export names as ANSI strings (with uppercase %S specifier) rather than
   unicode. This is because I couldn't manage to get the Clang preprocessor to
   create an L"" type string no matter what. This shouldn't be a problem
   though as the export names are all already required to be ANSI as they are
   passed to GetProcAddress.

There are also two changes to headers which are technically nonfunctional,
but not especially pretty:

memory.h is now laid out in the order function declarations -> #include
   "addrinfo.h" -> extern/SimplePage declarations. This is because
   including addrinfo.h causes serializablemap.h to be included, which in
   turn depends on some function declarations from memory.h. This could
   be fixed by moving extern std::map
   memoryPages to addrinfo.h and including that separately where this
   variable is needed.
bridgemain.h similarly has an #include moved downwards (bridgelist.h).
   This is because bridgelist.h depends on the preceding function
   declarations.

Currently the code (https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/development/src/dbg/symbolinfo.cpp#L173) calls SymSetSearchPath with the server you specify in the settings dialog.
SRV*C:\x64dbg\bin\x32\symbols*http://whateverserver but I guess you could replace the server with another local path to search first to prioritize that. (like C:\mysymbols*http://fallbackserver)

@nihuai the unicode support in that dump is extended ascii only. Rendering Chinese characters is very expensive but you can enable it by using a code page -> utf16 dump.. That is correct. The unicode support is severely limited because of the way everything is drawn. The problem is where to cut the unicode string. Tell me if you have any suggestions on how to improve this.. The issue with selection is because of the font. Unicode characters don't have a maximum width from what I know so you cannot align them easily.... @nihuai 

I've found that a character in UTF-16 can be selected properly ONLY when the selection is started from the column of odd number and ended next column in the hexadecimal region

Indeed that is the idea. Proper alignment is the responsibility of the user.
As for the selection. I don't think Visual Studio supports selecting the characters. It would technically be possible to implement selection with a variable-length column but perhaps some tricks can be done to properly align unicode characters so the current selection system works (clicking one UTF-16 character should highlight two in the hex dump).
While I don't disagree with the rest of your points I don't currently have any plans implementing it. If you really need certain things for unicode support I am willing to merge them in, otherwise you will have to write a plugin or something that exactly does what you need.

All the 'bugs' you found are not bugs but expected behavior. For the imports I changed the behavior to make sense more, for the references it will only find references in the currently open disasm section. If you want to find references to an import address in a specific section, follow import in dump (this will go to the IAT address), follow the section in disasm and then use Ctrl+R from the dump.
Alternatively, copy the IAT address (from symbols), right click in cpu -> search for -> all modules -> constant -> enter address -> it will find all references in all modules. (or use the command findref iataddr, cip, 0, 2). Currently you can do the same by right clicking on the import and selecting
the "follow in dump" option. I will use it for a while and see the best
usage... I can also add a menu to scan for usages in all modules directly.

On Wed, 12 Apr 2017 at 14:10, lynnux notifications@github.com wrote:

I figure out how CTRL+R works in ollydbg
There are two kind of address:

address belong to a section, whose type is IMG, it's in a module
address belong to a section, whose type is PRV or MAP, it's in a
   heap or map.

if press CTRL+R on the 1st address, ollydbg will only search in region of
module '.text', which it's think is the code region, no matter where
located in disassembler view
if press CTRL+R on the 2nd address, it will search in the region showed in
disassembler view
I think this is reasonable, I feel comfortable about this, and never
thought how it implemented until this post. I think, normally, there may
not have many references cross modules on a address. A address usually only
mean something to the module which it's belong to.
However, on 1st address, ollydbg seem only search the first '.text'
section, I don't know if there would have more section like '.text', an
easy decision is to search all section belong to the same module.

. Alright, so I reproduced the issue. Setting the command line from the Debug -> Change command line will correctly work up to 32kb. It will correctly save the commandline in the database too, but it will not correctly restore it. To work around it, use the Debug -> Change command line option after you started the debuggee and everything should work fine.. Try with this application, it's a small test: https://transfer.sh/4GBBA/CommandLineTest.exe

Code:
```c++

include

{
    printf("argc: %d, argv:\n", argc);
    for (int i = 0; i < argc; i++)
        printf("  %d:\"%s\"\n", strlen(argv[i]), argv[i]);
    getchar();
    return 0;
}
```

. Yeah that is exactly the reason I don't want to work on this. It requires a massive overhaul of the code or some kind of hacked, custom sprintf for basically something I wouldn't even use.

A better approach could be to simply highlight the redundant parts of the address in a different color which makes sure you don't lose any information while making things clearer at the same time and it is intuitive to integrate in the codebase.. I agree with the Actions -> part (it is on my long list of things to do), but I definitely do not agree with putting the variations as separate strings, because this doesn't work in many languages where the order of words is different than English or where the conjugation depends on the context.
Regardless as the main developer/maintainer of this project I know which things require a massive overhaul and which things can be seen as 'enhancement' and require minimal effort to pull off. If you are interested in helping you should take a look at http://easy.x64dbg.com to get started with small things so you can get to know the codebase better and not judge from a perspective of someone who doesn't know anything about the code.

. The logic is that olly swallows the exception and thus behaves incorrectly
with regards to the exception handlers it calls and then exposing anti
debug tricks. I cannot control what windows does with eip after I set the
context. If you want this behavior it can be turned on in settings. You can
also register an exception breakpoint on 80000003 and call the "con"
command if you want it for a specific application.

As for the "d" command, just write a plugin that registers your command. Or
just set the hotkey "d" to replace ctrl+g and use the goto dialog where
every expression is supported correctly.

In the blog post, the function address was 0xF7770000, and EIP was
0xF7770003
which means that the result (pushed EIP) was at +3 offset from the
function beginning,
that implies that the recorded/pushed EIP was the one pointing at the
instruction ftst (last executed FPU instruction).

[image: untitled]

recorded/pushed EIP (0x00141014) - function beginning (0x00141011) = +3

http://x86.renejeschke.de/html/file_module_x86_id_119.html
or
http://www.nacad.ufrj.br/online/intel/vtune/users_guide/mergedProjects/analyzer_ec/mergedProjects/reference_olh/mergedProjects/instructions/instruct32_hh/vc120.htm
or
http://math-atlas.sourceforge.net/devel/assembly/ia32_isaA.pdf (page 334
of 580)

```
include 
static volatile int gCounter = 0;
extern "C" __declspec(dllexport) void increase()
{
    gCounter++;
}
static DWORD WINAPI ThreadProc(void*)
{
    while(true)
        increase();
    return 0;
}
int main()
{
    CreateThread(0, 0, ThreadProc, 0, 0, 0);
    CreateThread(0, 0, ThreadProc, 0, 0, 0);
    CreateThread(0, 0, ThreadProc, 0, 0, 0);
    ThreadProc(0);
}

. Yes, the s format string function tries to heuristically determine whether the bytes at the address are part of a string and what encoding it is (utf16 vs ansi). The s format specifier uses the same heuristic as the disassembly view, you can find the code here. The point is to not list every one or two character byte sequence that by chance can also be interpreted as an ASCII string. Show memory pages as they were allocated (original allocation base + size), the only exception is for module sections which are also shown as they appear in the header (this is the default view)
Show memory pages as they are in memory (probably equivalent to Cheat Engine).

You can switch views by using the 'Switch View' menu option in the memory map. Note however that this has the side effect of changing how much data you can scroll through when you go to an address in the disassembly or dump. The command line for x32dbg.exe is not suitable for public use. The launcher uses it to communicate it's intention to the debugger. However, here is an overview of the options:
x32dbg.exe <filename>
x32dbg.exe -p <pid>
x32dbg.exe <filename> <command line>
x32dbg.exe <filename> <command line> <working directory>
x32dbg.exe -a <pid> -e <event>
x32dbg.exe -p <pid> -e <event>
x32dbg.exe -p <pid> -tid <tid>
The important part is that you have to escape your command line arguments if you want to use x32dbg directly, for example:
x32dbg.exe "C:\Program Files\Test\Test.exe" "arg1 ""arg2 with spaces""" "C:\Program Files\Test"
Will effectively run:
cd "C:\Program Files\Test"
"C:\Program Files\Test\Test.exe" arg1 "arg2 with spaces"
x96dbg
The intention for x96dbg is to handle the escaping for you. To achieve the same as the previous example you can do:
cd "C:\Program Files\Test"
C:\x64dbg\x96dbg.exe "C:\Program Files\Test\Test.exe" arg1 "arg2 with spaces"
Test

. I have used x64dbg before and setting a breakpoint is done like this:
- cheap checks for housekeeping
- call TitanEngine to set the breakpoint (write process memory + some other stuff)
- add breakpoint in x64dbg’s housekeeping
- gui refresh

Now when setting 100 breakpoints from inside the gui you get 100 refresh signals and a lot of memory reads that pretty quickly flood the message queue causing a massive freeze.. Yes that’s why this issue exists. I do not set so many breakpoints so no
need to fix it for me, perhaps somebody else is interested :)

An entry point of zero is actually valid (there are some examples in the corkami repository). I think a proper fix would be to move setting the entry breakpoint to the system breakpoint callback.. There is a misunderstanding here 😀
Currently the entry breakpoint is set on the cbCreateProcess debug event callback, which fucks the loader because the MZ signature is changed (the loader isn’t executing yet at this point)
I proposed to move setting of the entry breakpoint to the cbSystemBreakpoint debug even callback :). Oh and when an executable has a zero entry point it will start executing on the MZ signature as if it was code. Some special crafted pe file can then put a jmp right after that and transfer to the real entry point without making the PE file invalid. For DLLs it’s not possible to have a zero entry point.. I just checked and it appears that you cannot set a breakpoint on the PE header even when doing it from the system breakpoint callback. Probably the only possibility is to fall back to hardware breakpoints if an entry point of zero is detected.
Sample (not malware): entry0_.zip
