To solve this issue: remove yara from x64dbg.. There is no way for x64dbg to know that your function is __declspec(noreturn), so it cannot assume an int3 is the end of a function.. It was closed because x64dbg doesn’t know what noreturn is and thus cannot assume that int3 is the end of the function.
Often there are int3 instructions in real code (asserts, anti debug tricks) so we cannot say “it’s an int3, so the flow ends here”. This is why the behavior right now is as-expected.
It would be possible to add a data type “terminal instruction” and allow users/analysis to mark the int3. We can turn the issue into that and reopen it if you want.

On Wed, 19 Sep 2018 at 08:48, twifty notifications@github.com wrote:
While working within the CPU view, I often add comments and label function
calls. I do this mainly using the mouses right click to open the context
menu. The problem is when right clicking on a line which is not currently
selected/highlighted, the functionality of the context menu applies to the
actually selected line.
For example:
1  push 0x0
2  push 0x100
3  call 0xdeadbeef
If line 1 is highlighted, right clicking line 3 and adding a comment will
add the comment to line 1 rather than the expected line 3. Similarly, when
trying to label the function on line 3, the address will not be listed in
the label sub menu.
A work around is to left click the line to select it then right click to
open the menu.
A solution would be to also select the line upon a right click.

. WriteProcessMemory will call VirtualProtect for you, you don't need to have write access.. In general x64dbg cannot smell another program is doing something (it doesn't have a kernel driver). There some heuristics (like time passing, or certain debug events) that cause the memory map to re-populate. This is a costly operation, so it cannot be done every millisecond...

Also you have to take into account that x64dbg generally displays pages with their allocation size (except the pe sections, which have special treatment). You can right click -> switch view to see a more 'realistic' (but generally harder to read) memory map.. You can find the source code here: https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/development/src/dbg/memory.cpp#L27
Protection is the 'current' protection (depending on your memory map view this can be wrong, see source code for details). Initial is the protection that was passed to VirtualAlloc.. Hey, long time no see ^^
Currently the command doesn’t take a variable because there isn’t really a way to know how to convert the variable to a byte pattern (variables don’t have a size).... You can google for “uiAccess true” and find for example http://techsupt.winbatch.com/webcgi/webbatch.exe?techsupt/nftechsupt.web+WinBatch/Vista+UiAccess~TRUE~and~Protected~Locations.txt
This tells you that in order to gain the uiAccess=true privilege you have to sign the application (x64dbg.exe) with a valid digital signature and place it in a secure location. Don’t forget to set this flag in the manifest of x64dbg too.
If you follow these steps you will be able to debug other applications that require this privilege.
There are also some ideas out there to attach to such a process with the debug privilege enabled, but I honestly doubt that’d work.. Yes, this is expected and documented behavior. password: infected. I was thinking about the cleanup too, but probably it's good enough to just clear the exports/imports/whatever. Also another issue I see how is that I call vector.reserve with exportDir->NumberOfFunctions, so that could take up a good chunk of memory and cause a DoS too, ooops.. That malware is actually triggering an out of bounds read by setting the number of exports to be very large. Is there some guarantee on data having to be inside the export directory for those RVAs in there?
Adding checks certainly won’t hurt (as long as that massive casting isn’t triggering some UB), but like you said, probably a good idea to do a generic try/except just in case.. Sorry for the delay, been really busy recently.... Personally I would not use this feature. Generally you're not using the command line to do things like stepping, since there are hotkeys. However like you said, it would be easy to implement so a pull request with setting wouldn't be rejected. On the other hand, the code related to autocomplete/history of the command bar is pretty hacky already so the implementation shouldn't make that even worse 😄 . The script commands are not meant to behave like asm commands, just look like them (for example they also don't update the flags in the native context either for obvious reasons). If you want to write a 32 bit value to rcx you probably should just write rcx = 0x12345 🙂
There is some documentation, but this behavior has been like this since the very first release (before I knew what x64 does to 32 bit registers honestly) so I'm reluctant to change it. Feel free to update the documentation to clarify this: https://github.com/x64dbg/docs/blob/master/introduction/Input.md
If you'd like to add your own script handler you can do so with GuiRegisterScriptLanguage. You could quite easily use this to have a repl-like interface that emulates asm instructions in the native context.. Some helpful content if somebody wants to implement this: https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/development/src/dbg/analysis/exceptiondirectoryanalysis.cpp#L8. If you want a more accurate (but in my opinion often useless)
representation of the memory map you can switch the view with the “switch
view” context menu option.

. It doesn't have to be because it will be informed with the CREATE_THREAD_DEBUG_EVENT, the code for ThreaderCreateRemoteThread is:
__declspec(dllexport) ULONG_PTR TITCALL ThreaderCreateRemoteThreadEx(HANDLE hProcess, ULONG_PTR ThreadStartAddress, bool AutoCloseTheHandle, LPVOID ThreadPassParameter, LPDWORD ThreadId)
{
    if(hProcess != NULL)
    {
        if(!AutoCloseTheHandle)
        {
            return (ULONG_PTR)CreateRemoteThread(hProcess, NULL, NULL, (LPTHREAD_START_ROUTINE)ThreadStartAddress, ThreadPassParameter, NULL, ThreadId);
        }
        else
        {
            HANDLE myThread = CreateRemoteThread(hProcess, NULL, NULL, (LPTHREAD_START_ROUTINE)ThreadStartAddress, ThreadPassParameter, NULL, ThreadId);
            EngineCloseHandle(myThread);
            return NULL;
        }
    }
    return NULL;
}

I'm assuming you're executing the launcher, if so, it will just try to create a couple entries in the Windows registry for shortcuts and icons and that stuff, but it's not required for proper use of the debugger, just run x32dbg.exe or x64dbg.exe directly depending on the platform you want to debug and you're good to go. Ok, there was a syncing issue when calling the windows listing function and updating the GUI, a fix will be pushed soon enough 👍 . Sure @mrexodia, I just don't understand the nature of the bug, or even what´s the unexpected behavior here.. Well that's what GetWindowText gives out, if you guys have any other idea, I'm all ears and willing to change it. Ok, I think I found a workaround for this, it's just a matter of using GetWindow(..., GW_OWNER)/IsWindowVisible(...) to access explicitly to the correct "main window" of the given process and not just the foreground window. Doing this will also decrease the amount of titles of certain processes that don't comply with these two above conditions

I'll push a fix as soon as I can if this is the desired behavior. Done!. A project to implement OllyDbg plugin SDK (ollydbg plugins compatibility with x64dbg) was started some time ago in order to allow this: 
https://github.com/x64dbg/OllyDbg. Most of those conversion features already exist in x64dbg, tho not all of them in the same place, I mean in the Data Copy dialog.

Hex Dump - you have almost the same feature with the "copy" menu inside the dump dialog
Printable Text - you have "String/Unicode" in the copy dialog
Hex Stream - I just added it
Raw Binary - you have the "Binary/Save to a File" option inside the dump dialog
Escaped String - you have "C-Style String" in the copy dialog

Anyways I also changed the combo for a list....way better now! I guess that's all.. PR update coming up, don't merge yet. Ok I guess now its done!...you can merge whenever you want. +1

. I got confused because what you see in the list is not what you see when editing the command. For example, the constants are prefixed with 0x when editing commands. What's the reason for that? Multiline Ultimate Assembler is not designed for this, and it works incorrectly in some cases.
About the buggy command, the behavior seems inconsistent: if you click space on the command above (cmp ..., which is 66 81 78 18 0B 02), and then press enter, it seems to be re-assembled correctly. On the other hand, if you choose another command, press space, enter the command above (cmp ...), and press enter, you see an incorrect command.
...OK, while writing this, I found out the reason: if the command wasn't changed, it's not being re-assembled. It's enough to add a space at the end of it, and the bug can be seen. I think that this is confusing, and the command should always be re-assembled. If the bytes change as a result, that's not always a bug; some commands have more than one representation.
In general, I tried to play with a block of code and Multiline Ultimate Assembler, and saw several issues. Here are some of them:
- and rsp, 0xfffffffffffffff0 is assembled as 48 81 E4 F0 FF FF FF, while it can be as short as 48 83 E4 F0.
- movabs r8, 1 is assembled as mov r8, 1. Should be 49 B8 01 00 00 00 00 00 00 00.
  Edit: turns out this is correct, as mov and movabs are the same thing. This command assembles incorrectly, though: mov r8, 123456789, the immediate is truncated.
If you want to stress-test XEDParse, you can disassemble blocks of code with Multiline Ultimate Assembler, and then re-assemble them. The result should be the same, or very similar. It works very well with Ollydbg, unfortunately not as well with x64dbg.
. Thanks, I'll check it out when I have the chance.
I see that the new engine treats numeric literals as decimal numbers.
e.g. add eax, 60 is assembled as add eax, 0x3c.
This breaks Multiline Ultimate Assembler in several places, as it assumes that literals are hexadecimal.
Is there a setting for Keystone to preserve the old behavior?

. Found the fix, internally the breakpoint is reset everytime it's hit, and in the reset if, it does this : 
if(ResetBPX == true)
// Reset SW BPX Code 
else if(ResetHwBPX == true)
// Reset HW BPX Code
else if(ResetMemBPX == true)
// Reset MEM BPX Code
when it should be 3 If, so it sets back all breakpoints, not only one of them

. It actually is reported to the debugger in this case. It is reported to the debugger, and if the debugger provides an action to do with the exception, it will step over the exception. If you provide nothing for the exception, it will follow AddVectoredException.

The program I am debugging right now does this:
TlsCallback 0 -> 
Bunches of things for imports ->
Manually maps it's own exe into itself, and unloads the original ->
RtlAddVectoredException(1, &function); ->
Proceeds with loading the exe, but with modified start address and such ->
runs opcode 17h (which is an invalid opcode) ->
calls exception function ->
go back to running opcode 17h
I should also mention this is a 64bit application.

. I had a similar issue with x64 debugging and found the issue was with Actual Windows Manager - which always seemed to load a aimemb64.dll into the target process regardless of exclusions etc. 
I would get an exception error when it was just about to create a dialog (CreateDialogParamIndirect would always throw up the exception and the call stack showed a return from a aimemb64 module) 
Once i quit running that utility (for purposes of debugging x64 programs) it solved the issue. 
So as mrexodia has said disable any tools and utilities that may have hooks that might be interfering. 
One way to figure out which tool/utility/program is causing the issue, is to have a look at the modules loaded for the program you are debugging via process explorer / process hacker (run it without debugging first) - look for any third party dlls and take note of them. Close down those third party utilities, stop the services/drivers that are related to those dll's if possible, and see if that helps you in a process of elimination to figure out the culprit.
Tools like msconfig and autoruns by system internals could be useful to see what programs and tools are running on your system and to disable them from running at startup - which might help you as well. 
Hope that helps or points you in the right direction

. PLUG_CB_INITDEBUG has a szFileName field - the name of the file being debugged.
For getting a module base you could try something like
cpp
    duint entry = GetContextData(UE_CIP);
    char modname[MAX_MODULE_SIZE] = "";
    DbgGetModuleAt(entry, modname);
    duint base = DbgModBaseFromName(modname)
My c coding isnt great, so some of that might be off slightly, in assembler x86 (which i use) it is:
nasm
    Invoke GetContextData, UE_CIP
    mov entry, eax
    Invoke DbgGetModuleAt, entry, Addr modname
    Invoke DbgModBaseFromName, Addr modname
    mov base, eax
GetContextData is defined in TitanEngine.h which is included in the pluginsdk folder.
or you could try via the DbgFunctions ModNameFromAddr call:
cpp
    duint base;
    char modname[MAX_MODULE_SIZE] = "";
    DbgFunctions()->ModNameFromAddr(sel.start, modname, true);
    base = DbgFunctions()->ModBaseFromName(modname);
To get current address (from cpu view) you can use GuiSelectionGet
cpp
    SELECTIONDATA sel;
    GuiSelectionGet(GUI_DISASSEMBLY, &sel);
Again apologies if my c coding isn't correct, but hopefully it will point you in the right direction

Other potential work required or issues to be addressed:

I think @mrexodia has a work in progress document related to this and future development of the plugin api in general
. Plugins can receive callbacks for DLL load and unload (CBLOADDLL and CBUNLOADDLL), thread start and end (CBCREATETHREAD and CBEXITTHREAD) and system breakpoints (CBSYSTEMBREAKPOINT) for others events and for also a callback for debug string output (CBOUTPUTDEBUGSTRING). So possible to issue commands from within these callbacks using DbgCmdExec and DbgCmdExecDirect.
There isnt a way to tie a script to execute on specific events as far as i know, just globally and/or for start of debuggee (Options-Set Initialization Script). I wouldn't expect it to work with popup menus, just the plugins main menu entries. You can add similar menu items to the popup disasm menu for appearance, but not for hotkey usage as far as im aware.
The registered hotkey will then push a call to the plugin menu item, as if the user clicked that menu option, and will call the plugins CBMENUENTRY for processing as normal.
Or optionally register some custom commands and allow user to specify the hotkey they wish with the favourites dialog (Favourites->Command tab-Add), specifying the command and the shortcut key to use - assuming it doesnt conflict with an existing key of course.. I remember mentioning this issue as well in telegram when i was looking at doing stuff with hashes, its a catch22, as the CBLOADDB and CBSAVEDB are only called if there is data already in the user database, but with no data in it, there is no way to get the json object to then later add data to it, or to read data - to compare for example.. mrgreywater:
I propose that it should be compiled with the /MT flag which statically links the necessary msvc libraries. This way the requirement to install any Visual C++ Redistributable is gone. (This will result in a larger binary, but I don't really think anyone cares)
. I always thought it was forbidden to distribute those individual Microsoft DLL's, but I guess I am wrong in this case. Adding the DLL's would be a good idea.
. Debugged a little myself, the reason is that it only checks the page for PAGE_EXECUTE, but doesn't check for the flags PAGE_EXECUTE_READ, PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE or PAGE_EXECUTE_WRITECOPY.
Replace the Line 364 in stackinfo.cpp with 
return (pageInfo.mbi.Protect & (PAGE_EXECUTE | PAGE_EXECUTE_READ | PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE | PAGE_EXECUTE_WRITECOPY)) != 0; 
to fix it. I might can create a pull request, but it would be easier if somebody with repo right could push the fix themselves.
. This will most likely also happen with VC12 with debug heap. Release mode will probably work in most cases, as the memory is deliberately initialized with values different from 0 in debug mode.
. This line is removing the zero termination: https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/master/x64_dbg_dbg/memory.cpp#L436
edit: Exerpt MSDN to strcpy_s: 

The debug versions of these functions first fill the buffer with 0xFD. To disable this behavior, use _CrtSetDebugFillThreshold.

The memset at the beginning in the function therefore doesn't help in the debug build
Replacing the linked line with 
cpp
strcpy_s(Rights + 4, RIGHTS_STRING_SIZE - 4, ((Protect & PAGE_GUARD) == PAGE_GUARD) ? "G" : "-");
would do it. (the memset could then be removed)
. I checked it with both vc12 and vc14 in vs15, so it should be fine.
.

XEDParse is not actually the issue, it's perfectly fine at this point!
Since - i guess - capstone commits or before that by just a little, you introduced some sort of a
confusion, the short description of it would be:
instructions with pointer-operands referencing the stack (dword ptr SS:[esp]), will always display SS as DS.
So instructions like this:
cmp/mov/add dword ptr SS: [esp + xxx], xxx will always be displayed as:
cmp/mov/add dword ptr DS: [esp + xxx], xxx, but in fact they're still using SS
and this is where the confusion came from.
Moreover, you decided to hide DS from the "Assemble at .." window whenever it's used.
*Explanation:
In the old build, the instruction was shown as:
mov dword ptr SS:[ebp - 428], 0 (displays SS correctly as expected)
so when he pressed space, the stack segment register SS was already typed in
the "Assemble at..." window   --->   no problem
but in the new build (after the confusion was introduced), the instruction was shown as:
mov dword ptr DS:[ebp - 428], 0 (not displaying SS but it's actually using it)
so this time when he pressed space, DS was being used (and of course hidden from
the "Assemble at ..." window), and he actually assembled the new instruction with DS
while the original one was using SS (but not displaying it).
This is why the new instruction had a different size, and of course to compensate the difference
one byte from the next instruction was eaten and the rest of it was filled with NOPs
You can reproduce this very easily actually:
1) Type something like: mov dword ptr SS:[esp - 20], 4,
   It will be displayed as: mov dword ptr DS:[esp - 20], 4 (wrong)
   and will have the opcode: C7 44 24 E0 04 00 00 00 (8 bytes)
2) Type: mov dword ptr DS:[esp - 20], 4,
   It will be displayed as: mov dword ptr DS:[esp - 20], 4 (correct)
   and will have the opcode: 3E C7 44 24 E0 04 00 00 00 (9 bytes)
- In the latest build, If you replaced the current version of XEDParse with a very old one
  you'll still face this issue, that's why i told you above that it's not a XEDParse issue.
. Ah, forgot to mention that if the referenced register was anything other than esp and ebp,
DS and SS seems to be displaying correctly.
As a quick example, this: mov dword ptr SS: [eax + 5], 9 will display SS correctly.

. There is another problem here related to patched programs:
-Case 1:
1. Debug any program, then place a SW BP anywhere.
2. Change the instruction on which the BP is placed (so that the original bytes get changed).
3. Restart the application.
4. The BP stays as it is (correct).
-Case 2 (placing a BP after patching):
1. Debug any program.
2. Change any instruction then place a SW BP on it.
3. Restart the application.
4. The BP gets disabled (wrong).
This happens since of course the bytes after patching are the ones that get recorded,
so on the next restart (when all the patches are lost) the original bytes are read and compared
against the patch bytes ---> which will always be a mismatch.
Here's when it gets really annoying, assume you have the application XXX.exe,
you've placed some SW BPs on that application, then after that you made some patches,
and eventually saved it back to the file.
If you debugged the patched file, all your SW BPs will be disabled (case 2),
I know you did this to eliminate errors, for example in case the application structure changed
(because of a new version maybe) and the BPs become misplaced which will of course
cause exceptions, but what about this situation ?
Even if you recorded the original bytes before patching, the above-mentioned scenario
of debugging the patched file will also fail
EDIT: can't re-open here due to permissions
. Well, honestly i can't think of a proper solution,
but if you could do the following, it may suit all the situations:
-Solution 1:
1) First thing try not to record the patch bytes, instead record the original ones, because chances of debugging the patched file is less than that of debugging the original one.
(also if by mistake someone patched then added a BP, it will be disabled on the next restart)
2) When the application is loaded, check all the BPs and flag the mismatched ones,
if any mismatches found, then throw a warning to the user asking whether he likes to keep those
BPs or disable them.
- This way, at the end of the execution (when a stop signal is sent), there won't be any need
  to check for bytes again i guess, and it will please everyone.
- You can then make an option in the Misc.tab in the preferences to ignore mismatches
  by default, so it won't be annoying for people who know that the application structure is the same.
-Solution 2:
Just get rid of this check!
Seriously, was this needed ?!
if you already knew the bad consequences of this check, why did you implement it ?

. This is insane, turns out the problem was some kind of conflict with Kaspersky,
if Kaspersky is not loaded during account login (the protection is paused during OS boot-up), then everything is fine.
But if it's protection is resumed later on, then this issue occurs.
If it was again paused (or completely terminated), it won't matter, the issue will still be persistent.
@mrexodia I guess this issue is somehow "offtopic" since it's not the debugger's fault, feel free to close here if you want.
. #### Tested on the following OS-es:
- Windows 8 Enterprise x64
- Windows 8.1 Enterprise x64
- Windows 10 Enterprise LTSB x64 (without Anniversary Update)
- Windows 10 Enterprise LTSB x64 (with Anniversary Update)
Tested on the following Kaspersky products:

Kaspersky Internet Security (many versions, can't of course remember which, but it doesn't matter since this issue has been forever!)
Kaspersky Total Security v17.0.0.611(a)
Kaspersky modules/settings that needs to be turned on:
I have no idea!, but i guess the default Kaspersky setup will do the job!. I'll setup a VM later and see if disabling/enabling certain components will make a difference and edit this post correspondingly.

Exact steps to reproduce this issue:

The issue seems to be only valid for x32dbg.exe (32-bit version of the debugger).
Make sure Kaspersky is running.
Use a clean installation of the debugger.
Open x32dbg.exe (no need to run as admin) then from the upper menu bar select Tools ---> Preferences
In the Events tab  select DLL Load and hit Save

Select File ---> Open (or just hit F3) and locate x96dbg.exe (should be in the root directory of the debugger)
You should land on the system function ntdll.RtlUserThreadStart (the log should say "DLL Loaded: xxxxxxxx C:\Windows\SysWOW64\ntdll.dll")
   
Press F9 once to run the debugger (the log should say "DLL Loaded: xxxxxxxx C:\Windows\SysWOW64\kernel32.dll")
Try pressing Stop or Restart
The debugger will just do nothing!

How to workaround this issue:
A. Disable Kaspersky's auto startup from the settings and pause the protection


B. Restart the computer
C. Again repeat steps from 1 - 6
D. The debugger will Stop/Restart normally

EDIT:
also cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1F00 ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], 0
actually the immediates 1E??, 1F??, and  7??
will always be truncated to ?? until ?? = 7F,
then it flips to -ve values as shown in the 1st post.
so: 
cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1E00 ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], 0
cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1E01 ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], 1
cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1E7F ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], 7F
cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1E80 ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], FFFFFF80
cmp dword ptr [eax], 0x1E99 ---> cmp dword ptr [eax], FFFFFF99
etc...

. I completely suck at explanations and also not sure if the following is helpful in any way, so please bear with me.
1. The debugger cannot pause a process if the currently active thread is anything other than Main
2. The debug action Pause doesn't always auto-switch to the Main thread, sometimes pressing Pause will auto-switch to the Main thread and sometimes it won't.
I guess this explains why sometimes pausing a debugee will throw the message Error setting breakpoint at xxx (SetBPX), also as mentioned in the 1st post when this happens, switching to the Main manually will solve the issue which verifies the problem of the pause action.

Another thing (maybe off-topic) that adds to the problem is the instability/weirdness of the Threads tab,
see how (supposedly) the Main is the active thread (as told by the title bar), but in the Threads tab thread 6 is the active one

This actually creates a problem when the following scenario happened (the other way around):
1. Title bar says thread xxx is active (anything other than Main)
2. Threads tab says that Main is active
The problem here is that i can't switch manually to the Main thread since it's already active in the Threads tab.
So when the message Error setting breakpoint at xxx (SetBPX) is thrown (after attempting to pause) i have to switch to any thread then back to Main.
EDIT: apologies for the headache if non of this was helpfull. 
. For later reference, when this happens do the following:
1. Switch to main thread //
2. Press pause
3. Give focus to debugee //

. It seems that on the 64-bit version of the debugger, all instructions are assumed to be using DS segment register even if they're not, hence, the segment register opcode is ignored (or at least that's how it seems to be).
Old snapshot from 6/15: (correct)

Latest snapshot: (wrong)

see the highlighted instruction, and also this one cmpxchg qword ptr ds:[7FF7AB8DC6C0], rbx,
in the old it had the opcodes F0 48 0F B1 1D 36 86 00 00
while in the build it became 48 0F B1 1D 36 86 00 00 and the byte F0 was ignored.
. Oh!, that makes sense then.

. By the way, this has been fixed almost 7 months ago, if OP wants to confirm.. I guess variable names like aaa, bbb, ccc, ddd, eee, fff
are not accepted because it seems that the variable name is being resolved into a hex number.
In other words, var $eee, 123 and var $fff, 123 are exactly similar to something like this:
var $456, 123
var $789, 123
which of course are not valid variable names since they're all numbers, hence eee and fff are not valid variable names.
I don't think it's a weakness in the expression parser though, think of a situation like this:
var $qqq
mov qqq, 123
that would work fine, but if variable names with hex numbers were accepted then it would be confusing to the debugger:
var $fff
mov fff, 123
@mrexodia i guess a solution to this would be restricting the dollar sign $ before var names, that way instructions like mov $fff, 123 would be accepted since the user has explicitly marked the token fff as a var name.

. One more thing that may help, the function GetFileArchitecture() returns 2 (x32) because it relies on the windows function CreateFile(), which itself seems to be depending on redirection.
From the msdn page Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection function

... To avoid these problems, disable file system redirection immediately before calls to specific file I/O functions (such as CreateFile) that must not be redirected, and re-enable file system redirection immediately afterward using Wow64RevertWow64FsRedirection.

To verify this try CreateFile() on an executable file that doesn't exist in the folder SysWOW64, example "C:\Windows\System32\acu.exe". You'll see that it returns 0xFFFFFFFF.

It's not actually a bug, the string address is indeed stored in 0x1373094 (mine was 0x223094, generally the address of the string is stored in RVA 0x3094). But the instruction is actually accessing EBP + 0x1373094 so the debugger is trying analyze the string pointed-to by EBP + 0x1373094 not only 0x1373094.
And since at the entry-point of the application (before stepping) the EBP register contains some values, you won't of course see the desired string.
To verify this yourself, at the entry-point of the application set EBP to 0,
so that the debugger tries to analyze the string point-to by 0 + 0x1373094

(hint: set EBP to 4 to see the bad boy's message!)
Or you can make use of the "dynamic comments" feature of the debugger to always see strings pointed-to by RVA 0x3094 (good boy) and RVA 0x3094 + 4 (bad boy).
Add the following as comments to the instructions:
string at RVA (0x3094) = {s:[(:$0x3094)]}
string at RVA (0x3094 + 4) = {s:[(:$0x3094+4)]}

. This seems to be just a display issue, it happens when the precision in the FPU control word (x87CW_PC) is set to 3 (Real10) or 1 (Not Used) (the instruction fninit sets precision to 3).

. If i'm not mistaken, what you're asking for is called cross references analysis,
which basically displays all sources targeting a certain branch (all jmp/call/jnz/jae/etc... targeting a certain address).
If this is true, then luckily this has been implemented a long time ago, type analx in the command bar to invoke it.
This is the normal analysis done by x64dbg:

3 lines for 3 jmps, each targeting the same destination, but as you said if we scroll up/down those lines will disappear, also clicking on the destination won't tell you who is jmp-ing to here.
This is the cross references analysis (after typing analx):

1 line connecting all sources together, selecting the target will tell you all the sources, also if you scroll up/down it won't disappear.
Notice how the red line points to each source (each jmp) by a small dash.
Another thing that's very useful in the cross references analysis is that you could select a certain destination then press x to see all the sources targeting it:

you could then double-click on any source to follow it in the CPU tab
There are other analysis types if you're interested, this is the official documentation for them:
http://x64dbg.readthedocs.io/en/latest/commands/analysis/

. Thank you.. Oh, sorry for this duplicate, didn't read the mentioned issue before opening this one.. Scylla for some reason can't enumerate the APIs of one of the loaded modules from memory (i would blame it on lib.dll provided in the zip file), setting Scylla to read APIs from disk will workaround this issue.
Before debugging the application open Scylla -> Misc -> Options -> tick the option Read APIs always from disk (slower!)
or edit Scylla.ini and change the following parameter:
APIS_ALWAYS_FROM_DISK=1
To prove that lib.dll is the reason:

Make sure break on System Breakpoint is selected in the debugger options
Make sure Read APIs always from disk (slower!) is not selected in Scylla options
Open x32dbg.exe -> press F3 and select lib.dll
When you land at the system breakpoint go to the Symbols tab, and you'll notice that lib.dll is not loaded yet
Open Scylla and it won't crash
Now run the debugger (F9) to reach the entrypoint of the dll (so that it's loaded),
then try to open Scylla and it'll crash

Repeat those steps again but select/mark Read APIs always from disk (slower!) in Scylla options and no crashes will occur.. Adding more info to this issue:
Scylla fails here: ApiReader.cpp#L59, the function ApiReader::isModuleLoadedInOwnProcess() should return true but in this case it's returning false.
The reason is that lib.dll is not registered/stored in the std::vector ProcessAccessHelp::ownModuleList which seems to be only manipulated here: Scylla.cpp by ProcessAccessHelp::getProcessModules().
Hope these info help in resolving the issue.

Hit counter. There's a counter counting the number of hits. This is unconditional.

@torusrxxx, is it possible to reference this counter in condition and stop at breakpoint if the counter have reached some specific value? If so, what is correct syntax for this?
Typical use case for this is to run program debugging twise to stop at some point just before a crash will happen: at first run the breakpoint is disabled and just counting how many times (N) execution passed through marked point, and at second run the breakpoint is enabled under condition to stop once the counter reached N-1.

. So I took a look at this and this isn't an issue with x64dbg, but rather the behavior of Explorer.exe.
The same behavior can be seen using OllyDbg.
In short, if Explorer.exe is already running, the new explorer.exe will call a function named StartExplorerWindow using ShellExecute and the verb "opennewwindow", this spawns a new explorer Window and then it exits the Explorer.exe process.
There are also some checks made in the registry before this happens which lead me to believe there is a way around this. This could be worth a try: 
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/cc144064(v=vs.85).aspx
So it is just spawning a new process using ShellExecute and then exiting, which is why you're seeing the new Explorer Window but the debugger is reporting the process terminating.
. If you want to see this behavior yourself, You can:
1.  Download Symbols for explorer under the debugger
2. Go to Symbols Tab and Search for the StartExplorerWindow Export and set a BP
3. Run Debugger.

Looks like what you're POC'ing is something malware does very often called Process Hollowing, but usually after NtUnMapViewOfSection is called, the hollowed memory is replaced with some malicious binary code, then it continues execution. (which explains the violation when you try to continue notepad). I've had trouble with this technique with x64dbg as well, but I dont try to attach after the process has been unmapped, Im already usually in a debugging session when it occurs. It is interesting that Windbg recovers, I wonder if its using some kind of file on disk loading.. Oh nevermind, I think I see what WinDBG is doing. When the break-in fails, it suspends the process (threads) then it tries again.

WARNING: Break-in timed out, suspending.
         This is usually caused by another thread holding the loader lock

That message makes it evident.
More information form the Googles.

When you attempt to attach a debugger to a running application,
the debugger will first attempt to create a special purpose remote thread
in the target process, and the remote thread will call DebugBreak();
If the loader lock is held in the remote process, then the creation of the
thread
cannot complete, because the thread-init code requires the loader lock
to walk the list of the loaded dlls inorder to call DllMain(THREAD_ATTACH)
for all the Dlls that requested thread notifications.
If the remote thread creation failed, or it delayed too much,
the debugger resorts to suspendoing all the running threads.

wynick27:
I didn't make any change to capstone_wrapper. I compiled the code using VS2015 so only project file is changed.
. This is a bug caused by moduleBase added twice, Sorry I didn't do many test. It should be fixed by now.
And I also changed definition in addrinfo.h so that it won't get an C3848 error in release mode.
. Log should also support grouping like Debug, Script, Plugin and level like Info, Warning and Error so that we can filter log messages. But this requires all call to dputs and dprintf changed.
. Added set breakpoint on every command and set breakpoint on every api in reference view
This operation is extremely slow (several minutes for a module with 10000 calls). That's again because ui is updated every time bp command is executed.

. I think analysis hint and structure view should be added to disasm engine, just like ollydbg and IDA.  And the Instruction_t and QBeaEngine for drawing GUI should be an abstract class, so it can be changed dynamically to debug vm code like IL or from a virtualizing obfuscator.
. I can work on this once I finish other parts. The snowman IR is useful but the library must be changed to support symbolic execution. I think backtrace and symbolic execution won't be much code, only expression defination, translater and several algorithms.
. I fixed the bug in dbg message function and uses Memory template to allocate memory.
I also added temp code list support for encode mapping, addresses in the list will always be decoded as code and any other address that conflicts with it will be decoded as data.
Currently CIP is added to the list and if instruction in CIP is branch its target is also added.
These screenshots shows the effect of code list.
I write this test program with junk code at rva 0x1a, without analysis, it's wrongly decoded as call instruction.

After CIP points to that address, it's correctly decoded.

. I think we need apis for both local setting storage and global setting storage.
. This is also useful in implementing wildcard in command finding.
. MASM supports xmmword and oword, c++ have __m128, __m128d and __m128i. Currently display name can be changed to long or short, there is a map in the QBeaEngine.cpp and I already added a option for it. Maybe we can add more options.
. This database can be generated using clang with headers.
. Currently the indicator has the same meaning as ollydbg, > means jump reference, $ means call reference, . means analyzed(inside a known function).  By the time this part was written, encodemap is not implemented, . indicator should be set if the current instruction has analysis info (encode type other than enc_unknown).
. I know, maybe I'll resolve overlapping problem later. There could be gaps between basic blocks, especially in control flow obfuscated executable.
. Yes, it's a work in progress, I plan to add simd instruction as well, but it takes a lot of time to look up the manuals. The list is not all FPU opcodes, it's just opcode that accept float oprands.
. BpGet  and PatchEnum always get galled when debugging is being stopped.
.

I've used this simple C code, compiled with Visual Studio, to replicate - and so you can replicate on your side too.
cpp
int main(int argc, char* argv[])
{
    int i;
        // print every single argument
    for (i = 0; i < argc; i++) {
        printf("Arg %d = %s\n", i, argv[i]);
    }
        // never returns so we can check the output
    while (1)
        ;
    return 0;
}
Result without x32/x64dbg
If I run it without any debugger:
Expected: it prints every single argument separately.
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>PrintArgs.exe "i" "am" "the" "args"
Arg 0 = PrintArgs.exe
Arg 1 = i
Arg 2 = am
Arg 3 = the
Arg 4 = args
Expected: it prints a single argument
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>PrintArgs.exe "i am a single arg"
Arg 0 = PrintArgs.exe
Arg 1 = i am a single arg
Result with x32dbg
Not expected: it prints the single argument as if it were multiple arguments wherewas it should print only Arg 0 and Arg1 as above without x32dbg attached.
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\snapshot_2018-07-01_19-55\release\
x32\x32dbg.exe C:\users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe "i am a single arg"
Arg 0 = C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe
Arg 1 = i
Arg 2 = am
Arg 3 = a
Arg 4 = single
Arg 5 = arg
Result with x96dbg
Not expected: It does not seem to pass any argument using x96dbg so it may be that there is another bug.
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\snapshot_2018-07-01_19-55\release\
x96dbg.exe C:\users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe "i am a single arg"
Arg 0 = C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe. Debugger version: snapshot_2018-07-19_16-55.zip
Operating system: Windows 7 SP1 x64
Result with x32dbg
Not expected: it does not take into account the arguments I pass. It is as if there were cached arguments in x32dbg for each time I restart x32dbg.
To replicate, unzip snapshot_2018-07-19_16-55.zip in a fresh folder. Then execute:
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\snapshot_2018-07-19_16-55\release\
x32\x32dbg.exe C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe
Arg 0 = C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe
Then close x32dbg and try the following. As you can see arg1, arg2, arg3 do not appear:
C:\Users\exdev\Desktop>C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\snapshot_2018-07-19_16-55\release\
x32\x32dbg.exe C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe exe arg1 arg2 arg3
Arg 0 = C:\Users\exdev\Desktop\PrintArgs.exe
Result with x96dbg
Not expected: Originally it seemed to pass argument from x96dbg to x32dbg. However trying again, it seems as if there was cached arguments as described with x32dbg.

. But if current thread is waiting for another thread's semaphore. If we suspend all threads. Whole program will deadlock.
. Or we must determine if current thread is not able to allocate CPU time slice. And we should set current thread in "Pause" status. If we resume it before thread can run. We just set it to "Running" status.
. Ok. how about this:
``` cpp
enum THREAD_SUSPEND_STATUS
{
    RUNNING = 0,
    PAUSED = 1;
};
struct THREAD_SUSPEND_STATUS_RECORD
{
    DWORD dwThreadId;
    THREAD_SUSPEND_STATUS status;
    ULONG_PTR ulpCIP;
    bool bReached;
};
vector threadSuspendStatusRecord;
```
- Suspend all thread.
- Set current thread in "PAUSE" mode.
- Remember current thread IP in ulpCIP.
- Notify UI current thread in "PAUSE" mode. (Showing "Paused")
- SetBPX at current thread CIP.
- Resume all thread.
If:
- User switching to other thread -> Notify UI thread changed(If switched thread is pause so UI showing paused. Otherwise running).
- Thread reached pause breakpoint -> If status == PAUSED && bReached == false. DeleteBPX and bReached = true
- Thread reached pause breakpoint. But not current thread -> If status == PAUSED && bReached == false. DeleteBPX, bReached = true and suspend this thread(In cbPauseBreakpoint). If UI switched this thread to current thread. Continue debug.
- CIP already have breakpoint. -> Ignore SetBPX. If a breakpoint remove. Check threadSuspendStatusRecord. If some thread paused and bReached == false && breakpoint address == ulpCIP. SetBPX at CIP.
- Thread reached normal breakpoint. Check if some thread paused and bReached == false && breakpoint address == ulpCIP. bReached = true.
- Thread dead -> Remove suspend record.

jdavidberger:
I like the idea, but I think just using hit counts might be an intractable problem under most circumstances. Also, as far as I can tell, any sort of looping would be an issue. 
I think if you add a little more information though, you can get some very interesting analysis for relatively cheap. In particular, I'm thinking keep track of which breakpoint was hit directly before another breakpoint. Something as simple as 
hitGraph[thisBPId][lastBPId]++; 
lastBPId = thisBPId;
would give you a graph that you could almost just analyze visually. On top of that you could throw some generic graph algorithms at it to maybe get some automated analysis. I'm thinking you could pretty easily sort out chunks which were part of a loop -- it'd look like a subgraph with one entry point, relatively few exit points, and a ton of inter-connectivity in between.
. I don't think this is purely a result of continuing in a breakpoint, I think this has a small chance to hit whenever there is a state transition from paused to running. 
I think continues in breakpoints should be handled though; albeit maybe with performance caveats. The case here was running arbitrary logic from a plugin command which included some runs. I can maybe move that to condition logic, but it isn't clear how you'd do something like run to return in this way. 
. I'll look into the API for the async stuff. But I think the access should still be guarded, no? 
. If that is what is wanted UI-wise, I'd consider removing the clear behavior from dbggetdbgevents altogether, and let the widget itself handle the logic by tracking time between updates and subtracting off the last call from dbggetdbgevents. This would also open the door to maybe being able to configure that display to be in hertz, or the %1 events in %2 ms status. 
. Sure, but at no point do you have an exact counter right now -- it is clearing itself, and at some points is doing so within 50ms of the last time it cleared based on what the internal timings of the message queue was. 
Here is what I see as the possible ways to go with this, let me know which you want and I'll change it to match:
1. Modify getdbgevents to remove the clearing behavior, and let the UI display both 'total events' which is clearable by the user, and possibly events in hertz. This would have benefit of being able to remove the interlock on that variable; and would allow other UI elements to use dbggetdbgevents -- currently they can't because two clients calling dbggetdbgevents would clear the event counter and each would get roughly half the information. 
2. Revert out all the dbgevent changes. I don't think this is the best approach long term, but I think there is other useful stuff in this PR and I don't want to hold it up for what boils down to a minor UI change. 
. Fixed the dbggetdbgevents functionality. You can now click the time wasted widget and it will swap between view modes; although these still only work when events are coming in. Default is to show delta from last time displayed, plus the # of ms since then. 
. I believe everything is resolved now; and it should be ready to merge in. 
. Seems like a toolchain difference. Mine was setting WINVER to 0x601. Since we want to target 501 explicitly, this code is likely the wrong approach. I verified this by turning on 'Show includes' and there were no headers before _global.h in compilation units which displayed the warning.
Not sure why you aren't seeing the redef warning; probably it is just a minor difference in toolchain versions or something. How do you feel about something like this:
```
ifdef WINVER // Overwrite WINVER if toolchain gives us a default
undef WINVER
endif
define WINVER 0x0501
```
which squashes the warning and applies the right WINVER. 
. I agree something like TaskThread might be nice here. I didn't realize memMapThreadCounter was externally visible and reset, so I mistakenly thought that sleep(1000) wouldn't change any behavior. 
Now that I have a better understanding of the code, I'll replace it with a TaskThread which has the desired semantics. 
. Even moving that around I get this kind of thing: https://gist.github.com/jdavidberger/d6b93ffed5195a7ad6139f5d907fc278 in other compilation units. cl is giving a version as Version 18.00.40629 for x86 and VS2013 version 12.0.40629.00 update 5 for what its worth. 
This does bring up though that apparently InitializeConditionVariable isn't available on XP. I'll reimplement TaskThread with a semaphore and fix the header order. 
. I'm not terribly happy with this implementation, but I figured the options were: 
- Make everything require the userdata invocation. This would break existing uses of Register, and in doing so making call sites that didn't need a user data pointer to be uglier
- Make Function an interface and have two subclasses. Downside here is we'd have to change the map to point to a pointer of that interface; and manage some dynamic allocations. 
- Tagged unions for the CB function; however VS2013 doesn't let you do C++11 union stuff and C++03 doesn't let you do unions on complex types like std::function. 
- Wrap functions without a user data arg in a function that takes in the CBEXPRESSIONFUNCTION as it's user data function. Seemed unnecessarily maze like though; and I'm not actually sure if you could find a good way to cast CBEXPRESSIONFUNCTION to void*.  
In the end I just tried to keep it simple and easy to follow through the code.

ts55a:
I don't think the PC field affects the interpretation (i.e. display) of the x87 register contents. It only changes whether the processor takes the extra bits of mantissa (54-64) into account when executing FSQRT etc. but not FST/FIST. Cf section "Precision Control Field" of IA32 Software Architecture Manual volume 1.
I'm not 100% sure, but I think it is the value itself which causes the problem.
. this is on the latest Nov 9 2016 22:58 version, please reopen
. CD00 is the least significant bits of mantissa, not exponent. I'll try to debug it.
. I tried to input (extended)5.1, i.e. 4001A333333333333333. StringUtil.cpp:128 calls
    dd_real dd_mantissa(mantissa);
which extracts the mantissa A333333333333333 correctly, but the dd_real constructor converts it to x[0]=43E4666666666666, x[1]=43C1999999999A, in decimal 1.175979934698984e+19 and 2.536427310135064e+18. The sum of these two is 1.4296226657124905e+19, which is not equal to the mantissa*2^63=1.1759799346989838e+19. So this is incorrect.
The constructor reads
    dd_real(unsigned long long h)
    {
        x[0] = static_cast<double>(h);
        x[1] = static_cast<double>(h - static_cast<unsigned long long>(x[0]));
    }
The problem is caused by an overflow of FISTP (which is always a signed operation) in the static_cast<unsigned long long>. Here it doesn't return the truncated unsigned mantissa e.g. A333333333330000, but saturated signed 8000000000000000 and sets FPU IA exception.
Then the result of the dd_real division and multiplication by exponent is 6.2, not 5.1
I'm very surprised how this can work for most numbers, but probably the string conversion at the end of ToLongDoubleString somehow makes it up for the error.
I'd seriously consider using a different extended precision library.
. A trick that might work (sacrificing 1 bit of precision) is taking 
dd_real dd_mantissa(mantissa>>1);
and then adding 1 to the exponent
dd_real exp = pow2_fast(exponent - EXP_BIAS +1, &exp10);
. I like the idea of using a small library. According to my research, possible alternatives would be
1. a newer version of dd_real in David Bailey's QD
2. quad_float in Victor Shoup's NTL library
3. SCSLib (??)
Then there's of course the two big guys: GMP mpf and MPFR, a little cumbersome for this task I agree, but much more supported and well-tested.
About inline assembly, I also wouldn't consider it an option, but for different reasons. Converting IEEE extended to string, and also the other way round to support decimal input - a feature not yet available in x32dbg - is no easy job... Coding the stuff separately for x86 and x64 is probably not the biggest problem there. (I wouldn't bother trying it in SSE2.)
. That pretty much constraints it to float128 or inline assembly... QD is close, but still not a single cpp.
Did you try the shift 1 hack?
. What about this one?
https://github.com/rkennedy/exact-float
depends on boost
. Yeah, I meant coding something similar in C++ from scratch. But my C++ is horrible. I can do it in C.
So you essentially took QD's dd_real and condensed it? 
qd_real precision is not required.
. I absolutely agree. So would you eventually consider GMP or MPFR?
I'm afraid there isn't any library that is simple, maintained and works with MSVC.

. This is true when you are returning different variables, for example:  
``` c++
QString foo_func() {
    QString foo = get_some_foo();
    if (some_condition) {
        process(foo);
        return foo;
    }
QString bar = get_bar();
// or 'return get_bar();'
return bar;

}
```
This technique is commonly referred to as NRVO (named return value optimization).  
See here for relevant parts of the standard and an example given by it.  
(It also make sense if you consider that, at least with the Win64 calling convention, returning structs really means passing a struct pointer in and modifying it, which means you can elide creating the local function object directly and write into the passed struct)
. Could be modified to allow the plugin to provide an alternative instead of just filtering it (although I don't know if this is already achievable and it would probably be cleaner in another callback processed after the filtering happens).

merces:
Hi!
The default behavior for hexa/ASCII dumpers is to print a dot for non-ASCII characters. I think people are used to it and used to look for a 2E byte in order to distinguish a real dot from this condition. If you keep it as default, the hexa/ASCII dump output will be compatible with others. For example:
```
$ hd -n32 /bin/ls
00000000  7f 45 4c 46 01 01 01 00  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  |.ELF............|
00000010  02 00 03 00 01 00 00 00  b4 c1 04 08 34 00 00 00  |............4...|
00000020
$ xxd -l 32 /bin/ls
0000000: 7f45 4c46 0101 0100 0000 0000 0000 0000  .ELF............
0000010: 0200 0300 0100 0000 b4c1 0408 3400 0000  ............4...
```
On Windows, Hex Workshop for instance, follows the same pattern. While others prefer not to call it ASCII and shows UNICODE characters and replace dots by empty spaces for for non-printable characters but I've never seen diamonds or circles.
Apart from that, if you output a non-ASCII character in a ASCII dump (the column title says "ASCII"), it is not correct as @10miles pointed out, so it'd be good to either rename it or keep it pure ASCII.
PS.: Another feature to consider would be an UNICODE column, but that's another discussion. 
.

. I've noticed this too. The last 'working' build is 2016-12-29; the 2017-01-02 build and all afterwards create corrupted dump files. Tested on Win 8.1 x64 on multiple unprotected and non-packed x86 targets (to ensure it was no human error).   I ran all the different snapshots 'virgin' as they are downloaded, not overwriting my existing x64dbg and not changing any of the default x64dbg or Scylla settings before dumping (I did verify if all the settings were the same too).
After dumping the executables fail with the message "The application has failed to start because it's side-by-side configuration is corrupt".  Trying to load the dumped executables into x64dbg fails with "CreateProcess failed: ERROR_SXS_CANT_GEN_ACTCX" as well (= same error).
I ran sxstrace.exe on those corrupted executables (built-in Windows tool) and the raw error is something like 'Cannot read Manifest file. Invalid XML on line 0'.   When using the 2016-12-29 snapshot, dumping works just fine.    The most obvious and visible indicator:  the corrupted dumps of these non-protected test-targets don't show their icon in Windows Explorer. 
Also tried all kinds of settings within Scylla, including running x64dbg as admin; but it doesn't make a difference.  You can download my test-set to compare the results yourself here: https://we.tl/JSjVDsWho1
The test.exe is the original executable (it's the free and unprotected NirLauncher.exe tool simply renamed), test_dumped_2016-12-29.exe is the working dump and test_dumped_2017-01-02.exe is the 'corrupted' dump. To reproduce manually, simply load test.exe and straight away at EP start Scylla. Within the Scylla screen just hit [IAT AutoSearch] and [Get Imports] and finally [Dump], not doing anything else ...  I'm pretty confident it's some newly introduced bug :). Probably related to https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/issues/1425
You're using the 2017-01-19 release, which is about the last build affected by this; could you please retry with the latest 2017-02-05 version ? I'll bet that one works :). That's due to the exe-file having 'install' (or 'setup' or even 'launch') in it's filename; rename the file to test.exe and please test again, I'll bet it works fine :)  This is Windows behaviour by design (inserting SHIMs), not a x64Dbg issue.  kernel32.GetProcAddress gets screwed up as well ..... There's a mention of 'Thread created' in your log (TLS callback ?); it's likely the app is actually changing memory-page access-rights. Goto the 012D3710 address in Disassembly and check what memory address it's trying to access; if it's not 00000000 but a real address, look it up in the Memory Map tab and check it's access rights; it's probably missing R and/or X; try adding those permissions and then resume ....
nitrocaster:
I reverse engineer stuff and occasionally write in x86 assembly. In this particular case it is obviously redundant and makes the code too verbose, not helping to read and understand it. I believe that is the reason why IDA hides it.
Anyway, I suggest to add an option, not just omit these directives. Please note that I suggest omit only redundant ones, like the one in the first post. For example, in mov dword ptr ds[ecx], 5 size directive is absolutely necessary because 5 could be anything from byte to dword.
. > It doesn't matter much for your understanding anyway.
It matters in one case but not in the other. I provided an example for each case. Hope you understand now..
Gbps:
I experienced this same trick. It involves opening the currently executing file in x32dbg with CreateFile. In this case it's an anti-debug/packer trick, which fails for x32dbg due to a request for exclusive access to the file. CreateFileA will fail with LastError of ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION. OllyDbg does not appear to have this issue.
The issue can be resolved by changing the dwShareMode access requested by CreateFile at runtime from 0 (exclusive) to 7 (FILE_SHARE_READ | FILE_SHARE_WRITE | FILE_SHARE_DELETE).

balintf:
I've added PR #1790 to implement this, but I'm not entirely sure if we should also add default values for them, or if they should be just empty.
The defaults Search for->Current Region->Command and Pattern are Ctrl+F, and Ctrl+B. For searching in the Current Module I've added Ctrl+Shift+F and Ctrl+Shift+B, but in most IDEs Ctrl+Shift+F is find in files, which in x64dbg might correspond to either find in current module or find in all modules.. I have checked if it's possible to use QString::number or the underlying QLocale to make Qt do this conversion correctly, but from QLocaleData::doubleToString's source code I can see that they deliberately strip the negative sign from 0.
I'll fix it by using the existing STL-based ToFloatString/ToDoubleString functions on the GUI side and send a PR shortly.. I have worked on this issue a bit, and might have a PR ready by tomorrow. I can add the export names to the list in SymAutoComplete but there are a few open questions that we need to figure out.
Should it only add the exports to the list when there are no symbols loaded for the module, or should it add them always?
On my local build using VS 2017 _MessageBoxA@16 doesn't get undecorated to MessageBoxA, so adding the exports always is useful in my case.
If we are adding the exports always, should we try to handle ordering issues e.g for prefix 'A' eypoers Ax1, Ax2, ... will always come before Aa1, Aa2 symbols?  This already happens more or less due to concatenating lists from different modules.. As far as I can see there is no simple way to truly merge the exports into the symbol cache with the current architecture. It would require either implementing a SymbolSourceBase derived class that is capable of merging different symbol sources, or some redesign of the symbol handling architecture. Both seem to be too big of a task and changeset for simply adding exports to the autocomplete list.
I agree with @mrexodia that this fix should be a relatively simple prefix search, similar to the one already implemented in SymbolSourceDIA::findSymbolsByPrefix, and that we should do a refactor later, making the autocomplete smarter in the process.
I already have a working implementation in my local repo, but it only uses linear search yet. To fully take advantage of the presorted vector<size_t> exportsByName, and use a binary search I might need to modify it to store const char*-s or name + index pairs, so that I can use std::lower_bound to search for a prefix that does not have  an index in exports.. > To make it clear: if(IsArgumentsLessThan(argc, 2)) already checks the number of arguments. The real cause is Yara.
This only checks that the yara command was given at least one argument, but the cause of the crash is that x64dbg uses the second argument at argv[2], which is only valid if argc > 2. By adding checks before argv[2] usages and some default values for the argc == 2 case, I was able to get the yara command working with only one argument.

To solve this issue: remove yara from x64dbg.

Do you mean remove it from the 64 bit version, or remove it entirely from x64dbg? Could you elaborate on why do you think yara should be removed? (I don't use it personally, but some might find it useful)
. I've checked it and it's a bug that was introduced with the Capstone->Zydis transition.
The code in Zydis::RegInfo treats ZydisOperandAction as a flag, however it's an enum with continuous values from 0 to 7. The code in question:
https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/fba7af6bcd28381c4edd68f709a134f40befc9a4/src/zydis_wrapper/zydis_wrapper.cpp#L876-L879
I'm working on a fix for this.. I've checked this crash and it happens due to a bogus Debug Directory size in the PE headers. The sample contains a Debug Directory with the size 0xfffff000 which causes the while loop in ReadDebugDirectory to overrun the mapped file and crash.
It can be reproduced on a non-malware 32-bit sample (e.g. calc.exe) by using CFF Explorer to modify it's Debug Directory entry's size to 0xfffff000 and the entry's base address so it points to a valid address that's not a supported entry (e.g. to a random position after the original entries).
I have a fix for this and will send a PR shortly. PE reading doesn't seem very robust at the moment, there could be similar crashes with other malicious PE files. @mrexodia, do you have any suggestions on how to review and exercise this part of the code?
I was thinking of trying to setup AFL and/or libFuzzer for fuzzing this part of the code, and trying to find a collection of malformed PE files that could serve as further testcases.. Thanks! Those samples look promising, I tried running a few manually and no crashes so far, but I'll really have to automate it to properly check all of them..

it's a VS IDE bug. reported them lots of times. if you turn off linkers's suppress startup banner - u well see that there wrong /DEBUG:FASTLINK key passed to link.exe (instead of expected /DEBUG). it causes WinDbg to fail with symbols too btw.
so just clear the line Generate Debug Info, goto Command Line, and write additional /DEBUG key there.

GuardianArchangelJohn:
It's a bit of a big function, and it splits in a lot of places, it's the Quaternion.eulerangles function from Unity3D (converts from Quaternions to Euler angles). I wanted to check it to see what the underlying math does because a lot of people are confused on its function as is. Most of the time devs just accept it and use Unity's functions, and that's fine until you start interacting with hardware that sends or receives rotational coordinates like an IMU and it's in a different coordinate system like Nautical where Z is up vs. in Unity and most OpenGL-based software where the default viewport sets Y to up by default. In many cases, it's just simply a matter of rotating on the X axis by 90 degrees, but maybe I have situations where I want to just work in Quaternions and not even mess with Euler altogether, it would be great to know all the underlying math.
Basically, I just wanted to understand the math and know why it's a bit different than other more widely known Euler to Quaternion and vice versa conversion functions.
Luckily I can build an EXE with PDB symbols directly from Unity and debug it. Mathematically, it looks sound, unless your rotation pitch angle is 90 or 270 degrees, then they have some weird logic going on, and some of it I found out yesterday is happening outside of the function (in this case, when X = 90 or 270 and you convert to Quaternions, it looks like it multiplies the X/Y/Z/W by -1, but it doesn't happen until sometime after the Euler -> Quaternion function and before the Quaternion -> Euler function).
What I went and did was go back through and comment and just export the DB often just in case of crash. Unfortunately I don't think I have the minidump, if I can repro again I'll try and find it.
Here's the Euler to Quaternion function, this one's pretty straight forward: 
https://pastebin.com/ikW8c4AT
Here's the Quaternion to Euler function, this one I've commented a lot, it's the trouble function:
https://pastebin.com/AGVa3Pxc
I kind of figured that was the case on Snowman, but wanted to check. I'll start looking into taint analysis, I figured maybe a plugin will need to be developed. In the comments you'll see I tried to kind of work out what it's doing mathematically and keep tabs on the formulas. Looks like the majority of it is checking out so far, except for whenever X = 90 | 270 and you have other positive Y/Z angles. Then I realized that say your Euler to Quaternion gives you something like (0.7, 0, 0, 0.7), whenever X is 90 or 270 it would come into the function like (-0.7, -0, -0, -0.7), so I'm thinking the problem is upstream, but that doesn't make any sense if you have a standard mathematical function that you're reusing in several places in code why you would alter the variables prior to entering the function, so surely I must have made a mistake somewhere in my comments, but haven't been able to track it down yet..

dark2201:
I closed it because there's no such thing. The main idea was to keep track of values in registers and return values and save them as labels to avoid stepping through code. So you can let's say just run 1 function to the end and see what the values in registers are in labels. (for future analysis) so we have some static analysis capabilities like IDA. Even greater thing would be integration with IDA Pro, maybe something like TitanEngine debugger inside IDA so we can also take advantage of their plugins. athre0z:
The Mergings project card mentions that @blaquee found problems with this PR. Could you elaborate?. Try cloning recursively (git clone --recursive xxx).. Thanks for the extensive report! The issue is unrelated to visibility of operands, it was something I messed up in the progress of porting from Capstone to Zydis. #1751 fixes the issue.. The 0x is suppressed through the last argument you pass to ZydisPrintHexS in the displacement formatter hook here. The original formatter function has this set to ZYDIS_TRUE.
Edit:
Maybe just call the customized formatter function in Zydis::OperandText instead of actually installing it as a hook, so the Zydis::InstructionText output remains vanilla for easy reassembly?. Mh yeah, it is related to the size. The tokenizer doesn't support any sizes that don't have a string associated with them and it apparently works well with Capstone because, as it seems, it just wrongly reports DWORD size for such operands.
About the second thing: yep, I forgot to add .value in a few places in this func and it didn't error because it's passed to a vararg formatting func.
I'll drop a PR later today.. It's for this case:
https://github.com/zyantific/zydis/blob/master/include/Zydis/Utils.h#L59. Zydis has the same mnemonic constant for both far and near jumps.. In case you're wondering why this is the case: we stick to Intel SDM as close as possible and Intel doesn't treat them as separate instructions either..

If it's because of https://forum.tuts4you.com/topic/39851-is-it-a-bug/?tab=comments#comment-192434
I think I know what is the issue: I forgot to change (or rather just overlooked):
https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/f0fd4b7acfac7e93346d27054c3abce56549fa38/src/gui/Src/Gui/TabWidget.cpp#L14
It should become const QPoint &. I've fixed this in https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/pull/1744 and confirmed that tab detaching now works again.
Btw, this problem would be caught/non-existent if the project used new C++11 style for connects (which binds and checks for slot existence at compile time).
Also, I see no reason for signal to have a non-const reference as it's arg (pretty sure that QPoint can even be passed by-value without any perf impact, since it's just 8 bytes (2 ints)): https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/21d2d1c4e00ee77e975c9d84972f418d3de4d9d3/src/gui/Src/Gui/TabBar.h#L25. Also, path can be longer than legacy MAX_PATH, though not sure if it's easily fixable..

rmbreak:
I had this problem with snapshot_2017-10-30_01-05.zip but not when I compile from source at 9c639ddc5fb41973ea5f42fb4fea412aaf12acf1.. @qwerty245 did your save path have a \n anywhere, such as C:\Users\Desktop\Me\nogood.bin? This was the issue for me. I mistakenly thought building from source fixed it because I tried saving a memory mapping to a valid file path.. Ah, that would have been worse than where we started :p. Just added back stringformatinline(argv[1]) and removed the ReplaceAll in both string formatting functions.. Actually this doesn't look very good with instruction like call [0x00581124]. In this case the follow menu looks like:

Address: 0x00581124
Constant: 581124

Would it make more sense for the code to check if arg contains more than just a constant and if so, then display address and constant, otherwise only display constant?. @mrexodia I just took your advice in issue 832 about inverting the constant and address checks. I didn't find a way to check if a DISASM_ARG has both a constant component and a reg component..
qwerty245: Unfortunately the newest snapshot, snapshot_2017-11-04_21-36.zip, which includes the changes made at 9c639dd, doesn't fix the issue.. @rmbreak There it is, that was the problem. Thank you so much! .
IceAmber: so sorry that the version is a little bit old, the bug has fixed in the newest version.
twifty:
Any updates on this?. Why was this closed? A problem clearly exists in the rendering of the graph.
How about giving users an option to right click and remove the unwanted part of the graph? Or allow us select exactly which lines should be included.
Currently any function which uses vector allocate/resize inline methods will cause the next, completely unrelated, function to be included in the graph. This greatly increases the graph size and makes it extremely difficult to follow code flow.
A quick fix, for anybody experiencing the same problem, replace the first int 3 with a ret.
This leads me to the second problem with rendering the graph. Changes within the CPU view (assembly/comments) are not reflected within the graph. One must switch to the graph view and add an empty comment to force it to be re-rendered.. Has this already been reported or something?. I'll close this since it does appear to be a corrupt database. However, I should mention the problem is repeatable. It seems related to changing the instruction on the main entry point. If I instead patch the second instruction, it works as intended.. I haven't tried to reproduce the problem since. It was a combination of changing the entry point instruction, having a breakpoint set on that line and having a label set on the line. I don't know how or why windows update broke things, but it was working perfectly fine for weeks before.. Fair enough. How about an option to toggle 'right click select'?.

alogray:
As conceived in 1632 by Portuguese printing press operator Andre Filipe,
boxing was a gentlemen’s game in which two men would square off and regale
each other with stories monotonous for days on end until one of them fell
to the ground from boredom or exhaustion. Over the next few years, the new
sport developed a respectable following of a few hundred local socialites.
It was Filipe’s son, Andre Filipe Filipe, who developed what he called “the
punching strategy” in 1637 after seeing a schoolboy strike another in
anger, causing him to fall down.
When Andre Filipe Filipe challenged the then-champion, British ex-patriate
“Sleepless” Bill Bishop to a match, Bishop was the odds-on favourite. You
can imagine his surprise when while he was describing what he had had for
breakfast that morning, Andre walked up and thumped him in the neck,
sending him down “for the count” in the parlance of our time.
While it was universally agreed that the boy had violated the spirit of the
game, officials were unable to find any actual rule that punching violated,
and were forced to let the victory stand.
This upset caused an uproar in the boxing community large enough to spill
over into local newspapers, and stirred the interest of many outsiders to
come see what the fuss was about. The newcomers were enthralled to engage
in these borderline barbaric displays of human strength and skill, and the
rest is history – after a few spoilsport schoolmoms single-minded about
safety added the padded gloves, of course.
Today’s boxing enthusiasts fantasise about the newcomer that would rock the
ring the way Filipe did.
Classification of the modern ruleset has essentially locked the punching
strategy into place; but it’s easy to get caught up in the fantasy. Young
scholars with big dreams often enter the ring with their crazy new trick,
usually a variant of hypnosis. And though they’ve achieved the occasional
victory, none of the gimmicks have been robust enough to make it to the
big-time.
The real wonder, though, is that Andre Filipe’s original vision of boxing
is still around. Gentlemen’s boxing clubs can be found in cities all over
the world; you can visit one most any day of the week and see two erudite
gentlemen exchanging pleasantries in the ring.
Most people only come to watch a few hours of a match, and then leave. But
every once in a while you’ll find amongst your elders a stout fellow, a
die-hard fan, who perhaps witnessed that historic battle between Filipe and
Bishop, who for love of the sport must stay to witness the last glorious
seconds of wakefulness slip away, only to return to fight again another day.

Before submitting an issue, make sure it has not already been reported.
Then, make sure the following points are included in your issue:

Debugger version (can be found on right hand side of menu bar of
   debugger).
Operating system version and Service Pack (including 32 or 64 bits).
Brief description of the issue.
Elaborate reproduction steps for the bug/issue being reported.

Any issues that do not include these will be put on halt until
clarification.
If you have questions, be sure to check:

http://faq.x64dbg.com
http://help.x64dbg.com/en/latest/introduction/index.html
http://x64dbg.com/#contact

Additional information can help solve the issue quicker, such as:

A POC or sample executable that causes the issue.
A short clip or a screenshot clearly showing the issue.
Any supporting information that could help solve/understand the
   issue.
The translation you are using. Make sure to also test without
   translation.
Plugins you have installed. Make sure to also test without plugins.

1407 https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/issues/1407


1448 https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/issues/1448


Thank you for your interest in improving this community project!
x64dbg team

Thank you for your reply.
I often analyze the app hooked by security solutions.
Some Win32 apis  -CreateFileW, NtOpenFile ...- are hooked many times by security solutions.
Also the first partes of these apis are changed.
When trace these changes, it is very inconvenient to stop at breakpoints every time.
So, I like to use Log Text and Command Text in Edit Breakpint Dialog.
It is efficient to output it to the log window and analyze it.
I can use the log command, of course, but it is not easy to read and compare the outputs.
log "{mem;10@USER32.GetMessageW}"
FFF34883EC20418BC0458BD1488BD941.

It doesn't matter, I just saw that there was a commit update to 5.6.2, but it was actually 5.6.1.. Its format is matchstrA([esp+4], #index:"patternstring").  the value of index is 0 - 5, and the maximum value of index is now 5, you can modify the definition of MAX_TMP_PARAM to support setting more strings at the same time.
Just use this definition in the expression, you don't need to use setstring to allocate space. Reopen x64dbg, no need to resetstring, of course, use matchstr needs to follow this rule to use strings.

Just to provide some clarity around this, and hopefully to prevent any future confusion...
The Package Page on chocolatey.org for the x64dgb.portable package contains the following:

Software Site links to https://x64dbg.com/#start
Software Source links to https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg
Software Mailing List links to https://gitter.im/x64dbg/x64dbg
Software Issues links to https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/issues
These are links that are intended to provide information about the underlying software that the Chocolatey Package contains.
For any problems with the Chocolatey Package itself, which was the case here, there are additional links in the Package Specific section, i.e. 
Package Source links to https://github.com/echizenryoma/Chocolatey-Package/tree/master/x64dbg.portable
Package outdated links to https://chocolatey.org/docs/package-triage-process which provides further information about reaching out about an outdated package..

raiseman:
At first I thought porting Cutter graph (in its original form) might be a good idea. But if you try to compare zooming process Cutter vs IDA, you will definitely choose IDA.
Cutter's graph sticks to border. It simply does not allow zooming/moving to wherever you want. This is particularly visible on large horizontally/vertically oriented graphs.
So my goal was to implement something similar to IDA. 
And I think I did it, at some point it is even better :)
New mode is fully compatible with old calculations. Changes did not affect block coords, edges etc. 
And for those who might prefer old-style mode - it is an option, so you can always uncheck it.
I tested it some time and had not found any bugs (as of the last commit)
It would be nice if someone tested it on large graph, say > 10k nodes.
Regarding todo list: base functionality is done, there are some todos left in code but I think it is not that important.
Icons from Fugue
 . Just noticed that graph breakpoints are broken since that commit.. (have not updated some time) 
Easy fix is to rollback from
return zoomActionHelper() != 0;
to
return zoomActionHelper();
at line 2145
Actually, I had no any warnings for that part of the code... (QtCreator 4.7.2) 
Furthermore, this code (before zoom mode has been introduced): https://github.com/x64dbg/x64dbg/blob/5162450ff37d823d1713ba7da3ed310bf52817f5/src/gui/Src/Gui/DisassemblerGraphView.cpp#L1665
had the same functionality
. Yes. It returns the address.
Should I make a pull request for this? If no one sees any bugs left in zoom mode I would remove "beta" from gui option. . I think Shift+Z can be improved by adding a highlighting of selected block (like IDA does)
As for graph slowing down, the issue requires more in-depth analysis... IDA and Cutter lags much more on my PC.. Fixed

Also, I rather hate the idea of getting an insecure system and then trying to secure it, prefering to do it the other way around - start with the secure system and if necessary, release the rules a little..
